typeData.textContent:
This psychology course will introduce you to some of the major research areas within the field of psychology: the scientific study of behaviour.  The course covers several fundamental topics in psychology (for example, social behaviour, intelligence).  The course concludes with the topic of psychological disorders and their treatment.

This section of PSYC102 is a 3-credit online distance education course.  It has both synchronous (live; e.g., Q&A sessions, discussion sessions, and group activities) and asynchronous  components (not live; e.g., prerecorded lectures, online quizzes, and self-assessments).  Because it is a distance education course, most course-related activities are asynchronous.

This course uses an open-source text that is supplemented by many video-based lectures and online resources. In addition, the course contains interviews with some leading research psychologists and some educational animations.

There are no prerequisites or corequisites for this course.  Note that you cannot receive credit for both PSYC102 and PSYC100.

nodes.title: Eating: What, When. and How Much

typeData.textContent:
Welcome to the sixth week of the course! The video in this section details what you can expect from this week of the course.

Assigned Readings
You should carefully read the assigned readings for this part of the course (i.e., section 10.4 of the OpenStax Psychology text) before proceeding on with this part of the course. You will have a chance to check your understanding of the readings.It's important to note that not all of the material that is in the text is in the video lectures, and vice versa. So, it's important to keep up with both.

Oftentimes in research, observations are made that lead to researchers believing that a relationship exists between two variables. In psychology, this is called a correlation coefficient. In order to determine if a relationship exists, data is often first plotted on a graph in the form of a scatter plot, where each axis is a different variable, and a dot is placed for each data point. In this way, general trends in the data can be seen quickly, and where there exist trends, scientists can reasonably hypothesize that a relationship exists. For example, if the data on a scatter plot trends upwards, it is very possible that a positive relationship exists between the two variables being studied (Spielman, 2017, p. 50). The strength of the relationship can be numerically measured with the coefficient r, which can range from -1 to +1.

For example, you can decide to study the relationship between the hours of sleep and the GPA of students. If you observe that as the hours of sleep they get increases, so does their GPA, then you have observed a positive correlation. This means that as one variable increases, so does the other, and vice versa. If you observe the GPA decreasing as hours of sleep increases, then you have observed a negative correlation. This means that as one variable increases, the other decreases. Numerically, a negative correlation is represented with a correlation coefficient of a negative number value no further than -1, and a positive correlation is represented with a correlation coefficient of a positive number value no further than +1. When there exists no correlation, the correlation coefficient is 0 (Spielman, 2017, p. 49). An example of variables having no relationship or correlation would be if you decided to compare students shoe size with their GPA. 

The correlation coefficient is useful as it not only numerically tells us what kind of relationship exists between two variables, but also the strength of the relationship. When the correlation is weaker, the correlation coefficient is closer to 0. For example, two variables with a correlation coefficient of 0.75 has a stronger positive correlation than two variables with a correlation coefficient of 0.25 (Spielman, 2017, p. 49). Finally, one important thing to note is that determining the fact that there exists a correlation between two variables does not determine causation between the variables. What this means is that through correlational research, we can be sure that there exists a relationship between hours of sleep and GPA, but we cannot scientifically say that getting more hours of sleep is the reason for higher GPA scores due to the fact that confounding variables may exist. A confounding variable is a third variable that is not tested for that may cause or contributes to the relationship observed.  In order to make the statement above, an experiment must be performed since in an experiment, the variables are isolated such that any relationship observed is definitely caused by the independent variable.

nodes.title: Selecting and Assigning Experimental Participants (Janella Juan)

typeData.textContent:
A common observation is the use of college and university students to partake in a research study (Spielman, 2017, p. 55). An example that students of Psychology 102 can relate to are the research studies we sign up for in order to fulfill our human subject pool (HSP) credits. However, a question arises. Are college students a plausible representation for the general population? College students are known to be more educated, liberal, younger and diverse. The main issue that emanates is that it will be difficult to generalize the findings from college students to the whole population (Spielman, 2017, p. 56).
A preferable method is the random sample technique. A random sample is a subgroup of a larger population in which every person has the opportunity of being selected to participate in a study. This technique is preferred because the results from the study can be used to generalize a large population. Furthermore, this technique may remove the potential biases that may arise. Researchers can only use their results to generalize a population if their sample is large enough. The minimum should be between 100-200 participants (Spielman, 2017, p. 56).
After gathering your participants, they need to be separated into two groups: a control group and an experimental group. An experimental group receives the independent variable being tested, while the control group does not. The participants should be assigned the groups through random assignment. Random assignment ensures that all the participants have the chance to be allocated to either group. There are a variety of statistical softwares that can achieve this (Spielman, 2017, p. 56).
The use of random assignment is crucial because it ensures sound experiment design. It makes it difficult to observe any systematic differences amidst both groups. Also, random assignment allows researchers to assume that the differences observed between the groups are due to the manipulation of the individual variable. Imagine you have a list of 100 participants and you are asked to separate them equally into two groups. You decide to allocate all male sounding names in one group and all female sounding names in the other. This is an example of a non-random assignment (Spielman, 2017, p. 56).

Spielman, R. M. (2017). Psychology. Houston, Texas 77005: OpenStax.

nodes.title: Connections with Motivation and Freud's Psychoanalytic Theory (Coby Zamoranos)
nodes.description: A reflection on how Freud's Id, Ego, and Superego, suggests that our motivations comes from different internal perspectives

typeData.textContent:
A reflection on how Freud's Id, Ego, and Superego, suggests that our motivations comes from different internal perspectives
Id: (Instincts) Similar to the James-Lange theory, the Id suggests that decisions are purely  based on physiological and biological needs. This come as a foil to the Superego.  

Superego (Morals)- As the Superego is based around the idea of conscience and morality, this suggests that parts of motivation comes from moralistic goals eg. guilt. The superego influences the Ids impulses

Ego (reality, self control) - the Ego is known and the mediator between the above two. With its ties to reality and realistic solutions, the ego can manipulate motivation to keep it grounded, thus self-control

typeData.textContent:
Illusory correlation: when two variables are believed to be correlated, but in reality, they are unrelated. A common example is believing that there is a correlation between a full moon and strange behaviour. 

Reference for image
1. Types of Optical Illusions, (n.d.). Clear Eyes. https://www.cleareyes.com/eye-care-blog/201610/types-optical-illusions/

nodes.title: The History of Illusory Correlation (Jingxin Guo)

typeData.textContent:
Illusory correlation refers to a tendency to see the relationship between 2 groups that are actually not related at all. This concept was coined by Loren and Jean Chapman (1967, 1969, 1971) to correct a false claim that many clinical psychologists believe about the ability of projective tests to identify patients personalities, such as Wheeler signs for homosexuality in Rorschach tests and aspects of drawings related to patients personalities.

Rorschach test, or Rorschach inkblot test, is a psychology test aims at analyzing a persons personality and emotional functioning, in which patients are asked to say what they see in an inkblot (You can see the process of Rorschach test in the Clinical Example video). There were 32 clinicians report the 5 most common responses by homosexual men then many clinicians claimed that those 5 responses could help to distinguish between homosexual and heterosexual men. In fact, Wheeler signs (the 5 most common responses) cannot do that and they are unrelated. (Hardman, 2009)

The same situation happened in the Draw-a-Person test. Again, many clinicians believe that there is a relationship between persons personalities and their drawings. For instance, schizophrenic patients neglect to include obvious anatomical parts like hands and eyes (Julian Jaynes, 2000), and patients with paranoia would draw a figure with large eyes (Harris, 1963). However, there has been no evidence of this test that can identify patients personalities.


References
1.	Hardman, D. (2009). Illusory correlation. In Judgment and decision making: Psychological perspectives (p. 57). Malden, MA: BPS Blackwell.
2.	Julian Jaynes, J. (2000), The Origin of Consciousness in the Breakdown of the Bicameral Mind, Mariner Books, ISBN 978-0-618-05707-8
3.	Harris 1963: 148152

Illusory correlations keep us from seeing the real nature of violence in our society. (Hyman, 2015)

Given the recent rise in awareness about racial discrimination from the Black Lives Matter movement, this seemed like a particularly relevant topic to help understand some of the psychology behind racism.
	
The perception that people of minorities are more likely to commit a crime is a real-life example of illusory correlation. 

Why does this happen? 

When a person of a minority commits a crime, the media and society as a whole tend to blame the race/religion of the perpetrator. This creates an association between minorities and negative behaviours (Hyman, 2015). On the other hand, when a person of a majority commits a crime, their actions are considered abnormal (often a psychological issue of the individual - not the entire population) (Hyman, 2015).

This has also been shown in studies. In a 2018 study at the University of Louisville, study participants were told that there were two groups: S and T. Participants were then told about the groups positive and negative behaviours in a 2:1 ratio. They were shown fewer scenarios from the T group, making it the minority group. At the end of the study, participants rated the T group as more likely to commit crimes (Carter, 2018). This demonstrates how a simplified study can be reflected in society.

The result is that we come to associate the minorities with negative actions leading to unfair and racist treatment. The effects of this on a population are being protested today. 

References 
1. Carter, Rachel A., "Illusory correlation and perceived criminality." (2018). College of Arts & Sciences Senior Honors Theses. Paper 179. https://ir.library.louisville.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1229&context=honors
2. Hyman, I. (2015, June 21). Race, Violence, and Illusory Correlations. Psychology Today. https://www.psychologytoday.com/ca/blog/mental-mishaps/201506/race-violence-and-illusory-correlations

References for thumbnail images
1. Begley, S., (2018). Can zapping peoples brains reduce violence? Controversial study sees potential. STAT. statnews.com/2018/07/02/brain-electric-stimulation-violence/
2. Swanson, A., (2016). What you hate about waiting in line isn't the wait at all. Washington Post. https://durangoherald.com/articles/98489
hhh

While correlational research can help identify relationships between variables, the only way to establish if there is cause-and-effect relationship is to conduct a scientific experiment (Spielman, 2017, p. 52). The world is full of curious phenomena. To find answers to our wonders we can use the scientific method. Psychological science relies on the scientific method, which is data-driven. We can break the scientific method down into various steps; first, in order to formulate a hypothesis, researchers must make observations (Spielman, 2017, p. 52). These observations can be of the world around us or of previously reported research, and cause researchers to ask questions that help formulate a hypothesis (Spielman, 2017, p. 52).  

One area that has been the focus of many studies, is the relationship between violent video games and aggression. We might notice that our younger brother has been getting into fights on the playground at school, and that this appears to have started after he began to spend an increasing amount of time playing a new violent video game at home. Although we have identified a relationship between these two variables, as mentioned in the node on correlational research, we cannot conclude that one is causing the other. We could instead hypothesize that playing violent video games is causing our brother to fight at school e.g.: Students who play violent video games are more likely to get into fights at school than students who do not play violent video games. Then, we can design an experiment to test this theory,

Once our hypothesis has been formed, we must identify and operationally define how we will measure our variables (Spielman, 2017, p. 53). In the example of video game violence and aggression, our independent variable of violent video games could be operationally defined as games that include gun violence (e.g. Grand Theft Auto). The dependent variable of aggression could be operationally defined as the number of reported physical altercations on the school playground. We could then design our experiment to compare playground behaviour between participants who play the violent video game, Grand Theft Auto, for a predetermined amount of time against participants who play a control game with no gun violence, such as Minecraft. Janellas node on selecting and assigning experimental participants will go into more detail on how participants are gathered and assigned.

Spielman, R. M. (2017). Psychology. Houston, Texas 77005: OpenStax.

nodes.title: Eating Disorders - Lukas Franz
nodes.description:
A short overview of eating disorders
This node is not supposed to be connected to the obesity epidemic node. (We are unable to delete this node to change the connections)

typeData.textContent:
Anorexia Nervosa, Bulimia Nervosa, binge eating, and many other eating disorders all stem from psychiatric illnesses (Klump et al., 2009). These three are the most commonly seen eating disorders and they can be caused by a variety of factors, usually some combination of sociocultural, psychological, and biological (Culbert et al., 2015). These factors can manifest in many different ways; for example, a sociocultural factor could be the way that media glorifies being thin which could pressure people into starving or purging themselves (Anorexia Nervosa and Bulimia Nervosa respectively). A psychological factor could be a simple personality trait such as impulsivity causing one to gorge on more food than they reasonably should. Finally, a biological factor could be the link between dopamine level disturbances in patients with AN or BN which is not yet fully understood (Culbert et al., 2015).

From a psychological perspective, eating disorders can often come as a side effect of some mental illnesses. A 2003 study has linked them to obsessive-compulsive personality traits (Anderluh et al., 2003); other studies have linked eating disorders to Anxiety  (Kaye and Oberndorfer, 2010), parental figures with mental illness (Bould et al. 2014), and the list just continues. Given these connections, it is clear that eating disorders are not just a physiological disorder but also a psychological one as well.


Works cited
Bould, H., Koupil, I., Dalman, C., Destavola, B., Lewis, G., & Magnusson, C. (2014). Parental mental illness and eating disorders in offspring. International Journal of Eating Disorders, 48(4), 383391. doi: 10.1002/eat.22325

Culbert, K., Racine, S., & Klump, K. (2015). Research Review: What we have learned about the causes of eating disorders - a synthesis of sociocultural, psychological, and biological research. Journal Of Child Psychology And Psychiatry, 56(11), 1141-1164. doi: 10.1111/jcpp.12441

Kaye, W., & Oberndorfer, T. (2010). Appetitive Regulation in Anorexia Nervosa and Bulimia Nervosa. The Oxford Handbook of Eating Disorders, 73102. doi: 10.1093/oxfordhb/9780195373622.013.0006

Klump, K. L., Bulik, C. M., Kaye, W. H., Treasure, J., & Tyson, E. (2009). Academy for eating disorders position paper: eating disorders are serious mental illnesses. The International journal of eating disorders, 42(2), 97103. https://doi.org/10.1002/eat.20589

Anderluh, M. B., Tchanturia, K., Rabe-Hesketh, S., & Treasure, J. (2003). Childhood Obsessive-Compulsive Personality Traits in Adult Women With Eating Disorders: Defining a Broader Eating Disorder Phenotype. American Journal of Psychiatry, 160(2), 242247. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.160.2.242

nodes.title: Types of t-tests (Maya Radhakrishna)
nodes.description: Brief description of the different types of t-tests and when to use them.

typeData.textContent:
Week 4's lecture indicated that you can use a t-test or an ANOVA test to find out if a statistic is significant. 

1. The one-sample t-test for the mean

This test is used when you only have one sample of the population. The test determines if your result is statistically significant compared to a predetermined baseline (usually zero). You determine your t-stat using a formula and plug this information into an excel function (T.DIST.2T or T.DIST.RT) to find a p-value. With a significance of 0.05, you need a p-value of under 0.05 to conclude that your results are statistically significant.

2. Two-sample t-test for the difference of 2 independent means 

Instead of comparing your results to a predetermined baseline, you use this test to compare two different groups. The formula to find the t-stat is different, but you still use an excel formula to find the p-value and decide if your statistic is significant. 

References: 
Berkowitz, Jonathan (2020). Application of Statistics in Business [Class Lecture]. UBC Sauder School of Business, Vancouver, BC.

nodes.title: Kai Yang: The Movie "Inside Out" and Theories of Emotion

typeData.textContent:
Pop Culture Movies Inspired by Psychological Theories of Emotion

Any quotations in the following analysis are from the week 6 lectures for PSYC 102.

Movie: Inside Out

In Inside Out, an animated movie produced by Pixar, we are able to see how various psychological theories about emotion, such as the Common Sense theory of emotion and Paul Ekmans Universality of Facial Expressions theory, affect humans in everyday life. The movie also explores the difference between an emotion and mood.

Inside Outs main characters are inspired by Paul Ekmans Universality of Facial Expressions theory. Ekmans theory states that there are six primary facial expressions  happiness, sadness, anger, fear, disgust, and surprise  which are universal across cultures. Inside Out, which is primarily set inside the mind of a young girl name Riley, stars characters which live in the Rileys mind. These characters are personifications of the emotions of joy (happiness), sadness, anger, fear, and disgust; in short, five out of six emotions from Ekmans theory are portrayed in this film. All of Rileys behaviour is controlled by one or more (a combination) of these emotions, which is in line with Ekmans theory all facial expressions express one of the primary six emotions, or are combinations of the primary six emotions.

Whenever something happens to Riley in the outside world (the real world), one or more of the emotions will react to the event and take over the control centre in Rileys mind to make Riley react to the stimulus in a specific way. This process conforms to the Common Sense theory of emotion: a stimulus leads to an emotion, which in turn leads to a physiological reaction. The following example occurs in the movie:

Stimulus: Riley loses a hockey game

Emotion: Anger takes over

Physiological reaction: Riley punches the wall 

The film also differentiates between emotion and mood. The characters of Joy, Sadness, Anger, Fear, and Disgust are emotions. These characters witness events (stimuli) happening in the outside world and produce an immediate, specific negative or positive response to these stimuli. In contrast, a mood, which defined as a diffuse, longer-lasting emotional state that does not necessarily have an identifiable object or trigger, occurs when Sadness taints portions Rileys past memories blue (indicating those memories are tainted with sadness). As a result, Rileys mood is sad for large parts of the movie when she is not feeling a specific emotion. 

The various psychological theories visible in Inside Out speak to how influential psychological theories are in society, and demonstrate the important role emotions play in our lives.

nodes.title: Gender Identity: Trans* and Intersex Identities (Samantha Banfield)

typeData.textContent:
One of the areas explored in Section 10.3 of Spielmans Psychology is gender identity and dysphoria (2017). This past month, there has been much attention on renowned author J.K. Rowling and her tweets (and subsequent statements) about the trans community. What sparked the recent public backlash was when Rowling responded to a Devex opinion piece on Twitter about creating a more equal post COVID-19 world for people who menstruate. People who menstruate. Im sure there used to be a word for those people. Someone help me out. Wumben? Wimpund? Woomud? (@jk_rowling, 2020). Rowling has been criticized before for speaking up on Twitter against a UK woman being fired over transphobic comments, and has stated she refuses to bow to down to a movement that she believes is doing demonstrable harm in seeking to erode woman as a political and biological class and offering cover to predators like few before it (Associated Press, 2020).

There is lots to unpack here. Rowlings tweet implies that all women menstruate, but what about those who dont? Gender identity refers to ones sense of being male or female, Spielman writes in the course text (2017). This identity may or may not align with ones sex assigned at birth. Some individuals do not identify with the gender that aligns with their biological sex and experience gender dysphoria (Spielman, 2017, p. 347). People who experience gender dysphoria often identify as transgender or trans. Some trans individuals may decide to undergo hormone therapy or gender reassignment surgeries to help their physical appearance match their gender identity, but how one decides to present or perform their gender is unique, and should not be forced into a socially constructed box.

Rowlings words not only harmful to the trans community, but the intersex community as well. Intersex and trans communities share similarities in that they are both marginalized due to the ideology of binary sex and gender (Costello 2016, p. 83). Intersex is often conflated with ambiguous genitalia that cannot be described as entirely female or entirely male (Horlacher 2016, p.8). Other attributes, such as XXY sex chromosomes, are not visible outside the body. In th TED Talk The way we think about biological sex is wrong, Emily Quinn talks about her lived experience of being intersex. Quinn was born with XY chromosomes, a vagina, and balls inside her body. Quinn was also born without a uterus, meaning she does not menstruate and cannot have biological children. Would Rowling say she is not a woman?

Intersex and Trans studies raise the question of what kind of body one needs to have in order to claim membership to a particular gender (Horlacher 2016, p. 9). Do you have to have a uterus to be a woman? Emily Quinn asks, Theres a lot of us who are born without one (2019, 4:18) Intersex identities show that biological sex is not always black or white. We constantly change and evolve, the more we understand as a society, says Quinn. Nobody actually fits in a box (2019, 13:31).  

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Associated Press. Harry Potter Creator J.K. Rowling Says She Refuses to Bow down to Criticism about Her Recent Comments on Transgender People. MarketWatch, MarketWatch, 11 June 2020, www.marketwatch.com/story/harry-potter-creator-jk-rowling-says-she-refuses-to-bow-down-to-criticism-about-her-recent-comments-on-transgender-people-2020-06-11

Costello C.G. (2016) Intersex and Trans* Communities: Commonalities and Tensions. In: Horlacher S. (eds) Transgender and Intersex: Theoretical, Practical, and Artistic Perspectives. Palgrave Macmillan, New York

Horlacher S. (2016) Transgender and Intersex: Theoretical, Practical, and Artistic Perspectives. In: Horlacher S. (eds) Transgender and Intersex: Theoretical, Practical, and Artistic Perspectives. Palgrave Macmillan, New York

Central Tendency (Raija McLean)
nodes.description: When to use the mean, median, and mode for different types of data.

typeData.textContent: There are many different types of data sets that would benefit from choosing the right measure of central tendency when describing the data. It is best to first determine the type variable you are analyzing. A nominal variable is one where there is no ranking or order to the variables in the data (ex. gender). The best measure of central tendency for these is the mode because it will show the most common variable. For ordinal variables, the best measure of central tendency is the median. This is because ordinal variables are ordered in a series (ex. performance), and therefore, the median will give you the central variable. For non-skewed data (bell curve), the best measure of central tendency is to use the mean and for skewed data the best is to use the median (skewed right or left).

typeData.textContent:
Love is something most people seek throughout a lifetime, however what love looks like has constantly been debated through time and discussed by academics and artists alike. In order to achieve a healthy relationship, certain aspects about the concept of love must be understood. Looking throughout literature, the theme of love is very prevalent, often exemplified in famous poems such as Sonnet 18 by William Shakespeare or A Valediction: Forbidden Mourning by John Donne, and even plays such as Romeo and Juliet by Shakespeare. Each work observes and discusses a different aspect of love.

According to Sternberg, there are seven different types of love, each with certain areas of human connection fulfilled and certain areas missing. His theory assumes that a relationship is more stable with a greater number of components, that love will change over the course of a relationship, and that most forms of love are impure mixes. The first form is liking, which is intimacy only, in which a close friendship exists but lacks passion or commitment. The second form is infatuation, which lacks intimacy and commitment and is lust. Empty love is when there only exists commitment but no passion or intimacy; when there is both passion and intimacy but no commitment that is called romantic love, passion and commitment without intimacy is called fatuous love, and intimacy and commitment without passion is called companionate love. Consummate love is the complete form of love according to this theory, where there exist all three components.  
Examples of some of these types of love can be found in the above mentioned literature. In Romeo and Juliet, the connection between the two lovers is infatuation, where there is only passion. There is no intimacy since they do not know each other before falling in love, and no commitment. In Sonnet 18, the speaker compares their love to a summers day, calling them even more lovely (Shakespeare, 2) than a summers day. This demonstrates the existence of passion in their love, and the commitment can be seen through how the speaker discusses how every fair from fair sometime declines (Shakespeare, 7) yet to them, [their lovers] eternal summer shall not fade (Shakespeare, 9) and they will remain so long as men can breathe or eyes can see (Shakespeare, 13). As such, the connection that they have can be defined according to Sternbergs theory as fatuous love.

 On the other hand, romantic love can be seen in A Valediction: Forbidden Mourning as the speaker describes that [their] two souls are one (Donne, 21), exemplifying their intimacy. Furthermore, profanation of [their] joys tell the laity [of their] love (Donne, 7-8) showing the passion the speaker has for their love as they describe various metaphors detailing their connection. Evidently, the concept of love has been represented and described in many different ways throughout history.

Biological Sex: Beyond the Binary (Kristin Conrad)
The Genetics of Sexuality (Lang Kuoch)
nodes.description: A deeper look into the research over the past decades on the biological markers of human sexual orientation.

typeData.textContent:
In an era where outdated laws and backwards mindsets on sexual orientation still persists in societies and cultures worldwide, people have turned to the name of science to help uncover some of the truth. While for many of us the answer seems obvious; that sexuality is an innate, stable, generally unchanging part of who we are, some are still deeply entrenched in a mindset that it is a voluntary affliction of lifestyle choices. Desperate in our attempts to dissuade these hurtful and bigoted theories, we have found unlikely allies in the geneticists and neurologists, who have over the past decades discovered some interesting insights on the genetics of our sexuality. Specifically, it appears that sexual orientation, particular in that of males, has some significant basis in our biologyeven before we are born.

The hunt for the elusive gay gene has been difficult, and since 1993, when geneticist Dean Hamer first linked male homosexuality to a section of the X chromosome (Hamer et al., 1993), we have made some significant breakthroughs in the field. Firstly, it has become more and more obvious that finding a single gene that codes for sexual orientation is highly unlikelyrather it is more probable that a collection of genes interacting with each other is responsible for the difference. Genome-wide association studies have found that the size of diencephalon, a region in the brain with the active gene SLITRK6, consistently differs in size between individuals who are homosexual or heterosexual (Sanders et al., 2017). Further, family studies, twin studies, and segregation studies have all concluded that there is some heritability in male homosexuality; that is, when one set of a twin identifies as gay, it is also more likely that his twin will have the same sexual orientation. Interestingly, however, it seems that this link is not reported for females.
While this furthers our understanding, it also increases the complexity of our understanding of human sexual orientation at the same time. Although significant biological factors have been discovered linking to male homosexuality, not much has been found for female casesand yet, female homosexuality is prevalent in at least 1% of the female population in North America. So, what does the mean?

Well, for the future of our research into the biological side of things, it may mean that we still need to be on the lookout for other genotypic factors that come into play for human sexuality, especially that of female homosexuality. This also begs another question: if it is indeed biological (which now it seems it is), what could be the evolutionary advantage of it? Why has natural selection favoured a steady population of homosexual individuals (estimated to be around 2%-6% of the population) hundreds of years down our evolutionary line?

While theories have hypothesized that it may have something to do with having extra helpers around to care for our young (Vasey & VanderLaan, 2010), we need to remember that sexual behaviour is vastly diverse and complex. While there is no singular gay gene to be found, the overwhelming scientific evidence suggest there is a basis in our biology and pre-natal conditions, factors that we could never voluntarily choose for ourselves.

References

Alan R. Sanders, G. W. (2017). Genome-Wide Association Study of Male Sexual Orientation. Scientific Reports. https://doi.org/10.1038/s41598-017-15736-4

Andrea Ganna, K. J. (2019). Large-scale GWAS reveals insights into the genetic architecture of same-sex sexual behavior. Science. DOI: 10.1126/science.aat7693

Brian S. Mustanski, M. G. (2005). A genomewide scan of male sexual orientation. Human Genetics. DOI 10.1007/s00439-004-1241-4

Dean H. Hamer, S. H. (1993). A linkage between DNA markers on the X chromosome and male sexual orientation. Science, 321-327. DOI: 10.1126/science.8332896

Paul L. Vasey, D. P. (2010). An Adaptive Cognitive Dissociation Between Willingness to Help Kin and Nonkin in Samoan Faafafine. Sage Journals. https://doi.org/10.1177/0956797609359623

nodes.title: James-Lange Theory (Taylor Swift-LaPointe)
nodes.description: The James-Lange Theory of Emotion.

typeData.textContent:
Developed in 1884 by William James and Carl Lange, the James-Lange theory of emotion has two of its stages reversed compared to the common-sense theory (Barnes 2020). James and Lange believed that physiological arousal is responsible for eliciting emotions, and each emotion is associated with a different arousal pattern (OpenStax). The autonomic nervous system controls physiological arousal, either exciting the sympathetic or parasympathetic nervous systems, depending on the stimulus. Symptoms of the sympathetic nervous system include increased respiration, increased perspiration, dilating of the pupils, and accelerating of the heart. The parasympathetic nervous system is the opposite: decreased respiration, decreased perspiration, contracting of the pupils, and slowing of the heart (Barnes 2020). Depending on the stimulus, various factors of the sympathetic or parasympathetic nervous systems will be excited, and this combination will elicit an emotion. The three stages of the James-Lange theory are (1) the stimulus, which elicits (2) the arousal, which in turn elicits (3) the emotion.

For example, imagine Macy's family is throwing her a surprise birthday party. She enters the dark house and turns on a light. Her family and friends jump up and shout "Surprise!" - the stimulus. Macy's heart immediately starts to pound and her muscles tense - the physiological arousal. According to the James-Lange theory, this arousal is what elicits the emotion of surprise.

However, many psychologists do not agree with the James-Lange theory of emotion. There are several factors that undermine its validity. First, humans display a wide range of emotions, and according to the James-Lange theory there would need to be many different arousal patterns, one for each emotion. However, research has concluded that the emotions of fear, anger, joy, and surprise all have the same or very similar arousal patterns (Barnes 2020). Second, physiological arousal is not necessary for emotion, and vice versa. A person can feel a certain emotion without the corresponding arousal pattern, and a person can experience an arousal pattern without the corresponding emotion. Finally, some psychologists believe that physical arousal patterns are too slow to occur before and elicit the rapid conscious emotions we experience (Barnes 2020). Despite these oppositions, there is evidence both for and against the James-Lange theory of emotion (OpenStax).

References
Barnes, Steven J (2020). "Week 6, Lecture 1: Theories of Emotion." [Video].
OpenStax, Psychology. OpenStax CNX. Oct 31, 2018.

nodes.title: Risk Factors for Eating Disorders (Teresa Liao)

typeData.textContent:
Eating disorders are mental illnesses recognised by the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5). These conditions are complex and are still being studied today. Researchers generally agree that eating disorders arises from some combination of biological, psychological, and socio-cultural factors. Anyone can develop an eating disorder but having more risk factors increases a persons likelihood of developing an eating disorder.


Biological Factors

-Family History of Eating Disorders (Bulik, Sullivan, & Kendler, 2003; Strober, 2000).

-Type 1 Diabetes (Jones et. al., 2000).

Eating disorders in diabetic subjects are associated with the omission of insulin. Initiation of insulin treatment is often accompanied by weight gain.


Psychological Factors

-Childhood Obsessive Compulsive Personality Traits.

These traits include perfectionism, inflexibility, excessive doubt and cautiousness, and drive for order and symmetry (Anderluh et. al., 2003).

-Traumatic Experiences.

These can include but are not limited to physical, sexual, and/or emotional abuse, neglect, and victimization. From research data, basically any experience that can produce PTSD, partial PTSD, or any form of clinically significant anxiety (Brewerton, 2007, p. 287).

-Depression and Anxiety.

There are studies that support that eating disorders are sequela of depression and anxiety disorders, but it is also likely that depression, anxiety, and eating disorders share some etiological factors (Brownell, & Walsh, 2018).

-High Neurotic Personality and Low Self-Esteem (Cervera et al., 2003).

Neuroticism is a personality trait that consist of the tendency be in negative or anxious emotional state. People with neurotic personality also tend be in more depressive mood.


Socio-Cultural Factors

-Media Portrayal of Ideal Body (Lawrie, Sullivan, Davies, & Hill, 2006).

-Participation in Sports that Emphasis Body Shape or Leanness (Durme, Goossens, & Braet, 2012; Kong & Harris, 2014).

-Teasing or Bullying.

-Abusive Environment.


Other Factors

-Having Parents with Bipolar Affective Disorder, Personality Disorder, Anxiety, or Depression. 

Research shows that there is a correlation between parents with mental illnesses and their offspring developing eating disorders, but it is still unclear whether the eating disorder arises from genetics or the environment or a combination of both (Bould et. al., 2014).


References

Anderluh, M. B., Tchanturia, K., Rabe-Hesketh, S., & Treasure, J. (2003). Childhood Obsessive Compulsive Personality Traits in Adult Women With Eating Disorders: Defining a Broader Eating Disorder Phenotype. American Journal of Psychiatry, 160(2), 242-247. doi:10.1176/appi.ajp.160.2.242

Bould, H., Koupil, I., Dalman, C., Destavola, B., Lewis, G., & Magnusson, C. (2014). Parental mental illness and eating disorders in offspring. International Journal of Eating 	Disorders, 48(4), 383-391. doi:10.1002/eat.22325

Brewerton, T. (2007). Eating Disorders, Trauma, and Comorbidity: Focus on PTSD. Eating disorders, 15, 285-304. Doi:10.1080/10640260701454311.

Brownell, K. D., & Walsh, B. T. (2018). Eating disorders and obesity: A comprehensive handbook. New York, NY: The Guilford Press.

Bulik, C. M., Sullivan, P. F., & Kendler, K. S. (2003). Genetic and environmental contributions to obesity and binge eating. International Journal of Eating Disorders, 33(3), 293-298. doi:10.1002/eat.10140

Cervera, S., Lahortiga, F., Martnez-Gonzlez, M. A., Gual, P., Irala-Estvez, J. D., & Alonso, Y (2003). Neuroticism and low self-esteem as risk factors for incident eating disorders in a prospective cohort study. International Journal of Eating Disorders, 33(3), 271-280. doi:10.1002/eat.10147

nodes.title: Problems with Measures of Central Tendency (Fallon Furkalo)
nodes.description: An example of how the word 'average' can mean different things in different scenarios.

typeData.textContent: When measures of central tendency are considered on their own, this can be a problem. They only vaguely describe a data set, and any single one of them can mean average. This is very important as the impreciseness of the word average can be very useful in certain situations. For example, if we have two plots, one a perfect bell curve where the mean, median, and mode are all the same. The other is a negatively skewed distribution where the median is larger than the mean, and the mode is larger than the median. Say these two curves are for homelessness in the city of Vancouver in 2000 (the perfect bell curve) and 2015 (the skewed distribution). Based on your political standpoint, you can take the data set and come up with whatever scenario best fits your needs. For example, you could say, The average number of homeless people has increased! when describing the mode. You can say, The average number of homeless people has decreased! if you focus on the mean. Or you could say, The average number of homeless people hasnt changed! if you concentrate on the median. This illustrates how useful the ambiguity of the word average can be. It makes it incredibly easy to interpret data that best serve someone's needs.

nodes.title: Flashcards for the amygdala's role in emotion (Amanda Baker)
Mask-Making: Universal Expressions of Emotion and Expressive Arts Therapy (Nathan Cottell; Group: fernathan)

typeData.textContent:
Part of my training in Expressive Arts Therapy involved a course in mask and clown work. This modality is a powerful avenue for self-discovery and empowerment; it is particularly useful for helping people improve their relationship to their emotions. Creating a mask involves exploring and externalizing emotions, both through the physical creation of the mask itself and through embodying the mask in performance.
 
	The four masks displayed in the next node are masks I created during my training. Once a mask is sculpted and painted, the process of creating a unique persona for the mask begins. This process is greatly informed by the theories and principles of emotion we studied in Psychology 102. Part of the process of embodying each mask-persona involves experimenting with the six universal expressions of emotion described by Ekman et al.: anger, fear, disgust, happiness, sadness, and surprise. "Wearing" each of these emotional expressions while embodying a mask-persona creates a safe space for people to express emotions in a bodily and vocal way. Creating this space is essential to therapy: this experiential work allows people to connect with their emotional life on both a cognitive and physiological level. By observing their physiological responses (such as the movement of the diaphragm) to portraying a particular emotion, participants can learn to recognize and accept these emotions as they come up in real life contexts. This greater awareness is the first step to healthier emotional regulation and self acceptance.

nodes.title: Paul Ekman's Findings (Fernando Ng; Group: fernathan)
nodes.description: This node will cover Ekman's studies on facial expressions, specifically microexpressions and how to differentiate between them.

typeData.textContent:
Continuing on Nathan's explanation of Ekman's role on the six universal expressions, this node will give a timeline on Ekman's studies and specifically microexpressions and how to differentiate between them.

1950's: Ekman begins research on facial and physical expressions and emotions. Also achieves his PhD in clinical psychology @Adelphi University.

 1960's: Ekman begins to familiarize and study cross-cultural studies of non-verbal behaviour and conduct. The clinical cases he studied involved patients and challenging their emotional state, attempting to find lies through their appearance in films. Ekman then discovers microexpressions through slow motion footage in these cases. In this study, Ekman would spot negative microexpressions that patients would try to hide through their positive looking faces.

Microexpressions: Real, facial expressions that can be seen through fake expressions in slow motion footage, roughly in 0.05 seconds interval.

1970's: Through Ekmans findings in facial expressions, the development of Facial Action Coding System (also known as FACS) was invented. The system allowed human coders to code in almost any facial expression imaginable, allowing precise touches and interpretation of how the face moved. Used action units (AU's) as individual components of movement.

1980s and onwards: Ekman releases books on his findings, his most famous book called Telling Lies. Through his research, he would continue to teach others on the practice of detecting deception and earn awards for his valuable contributions in his career. 
In May 11, 2009; edition of Time magazine, he was named one of the top 100 most influential people.

Sources: https://www.paulekman.com/about/paul-ekman/
https://www.noldus.com/applications/facial-action-coding-system
https://www.paulekman.com/facial-action-coding-system/
http://totallyhistory.com/paul-ekman/#:~:text=Paul%20Ekman%20is%20a%20famous,lie%20detector%20in%20the%20world.

nodes.title: Physiology and Biology of Emotions (nintendosquad - Jonathan Liu)

typeData.textContent: The limbic system part of the brain focuses on emotions and memory. As the functions differ from section to section, so does their purpose. The limbic system composes of the hypothalamus, the thalamus, the amygdala, and the hippocampus. The hypothalamus helps activate the sympathetic nervous system which plays a part in emotional reactions. The thalamus acts as a sensory relay center for neurons to the amygdala. The amygdala process in emotional information and sends it out to the cortical structures. The amygdala also contains various sub-nuclei which include the basolateral complex, which focuses on conditioning and attaching emotional value to memory, and the central nucleus, which plays a role in attention. The last structure is the hippocampus which acts as an emotional processor and is liked to certain mood and anxiety disorders.

nodes.title: How to Achieve Maslow's Self-Actualization (Daniel Elesin)
nodes.description: In this short text, I explain how to achieve self-actualization from Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs, and the characteristics of individuals who have achieved self-actualization.

typeData.textContent:
We learned about Maslows Hierarchy of Needs, however, we did not learn how to achieve the highest need, self-actualization.

In Maslows Hierarchy of Needs, Maslow asserted that there are five fundamental needs that all of humankind requires: physiological, security, social, esteem, and self-actualization. According to Maslow, an individual must achieve the lower-level needs before they can achieve the higher-level needs. For instance, a persons physiological needs must be met before their security needs are met.

At the top of Maslows Hierarchy of Needs is self-actualization, when an individual realizes their full potential and becomes the best version of themselves.

In his paper, Self-Actualizing People: a Study of Psychological Health, Maslow explores 13 characteristics common to individuals who have achieved self-actualization. Typically, self-actualized people tend to live independently, are comfortable with the unknown, accept themselves and others for who they are, have a sense of reality and truth, have a firm value system, enjoy meaningful friendships, are spontaneous, are kind and accepting, are creative, focus on the bigger picture rather than their own life, desire privacy, are intrinsically motivated, appreciate joyful, peaceful moments, and have an increased identification with others.

To achieve self-actualization, Maslow presents 8 suggestions in his book, "The Farther Reaches of Human Nature." The first suggestion is to live life in the moment. Next, Maslow recommends that individuals should pay attention to how they choose, considering life is significantly dependent on the choices made. Thirdly, Maslow advises that people should let their true selves emerge, and should not be influenced by the world. His fourth suggestion is to be honest in all situations. Individuals should take responsibility for their actions. Maslows fifth piece of advice is similar to his third suggestion: people should listen to themselves as they embark on their unique journeys through life. His sixth recommendation explores the idea that hard work is the key to unlocking ones full potential. Next, Maslow advises individuals to set up conditions for peak experiences. Maslows eighth and final suggestion regards psychopathologies, and the importance of understanding dislikes to ensure that unpleasantness does not end up controlling ones life. 

Although achieving self-actualization is a journey that can take many years to accomplish, the end results are fulfilling, making it a journey worth taking.

Sources: 
1) https://www.psychologytoday.com/ca/blog/moral-landscapes/201802/how-get-the-path-self-actualization
2) https://scottjeffrey.com/self-actualization/

nodes.title: Comparing the Four Theories of Emotion (Evelyn Sun)

typeData.textContent:
Based on what weve learned in chapter 6, four theories of emotion are very important contents about understanding how our emotion is produced. Even though the lectures and the readings provided enough information, many people still cant distinguish those four theories of emotion well (including me). Therefore, I am writing this essay in order to analyze them more detailedly and give a clear distinction.

First of all, The James-Langer theory of emotion and the Cannon-Bard theory of emotion are relatively easier to distinguish. The James-Langer theory suggests that emotions derive from physical feedback. More specifically, it is said that arousal leads to physical responses, which in turn lead to emotional experiences.

The Cannon-Bard theory suggests that emotions must be produced after a series of responses. They are produced after the following path: Arousal - sensory organ - thalamus - brain - emotion - sympathetic nerve - physiological response. Meanwhile, emotional and physiological responses are produced at the same time, both are controlled by the thalamus.

As you can see from here, the similarity of these two theories is that they both have arousals, physiological responses, and emotions. Meanwhile, they are different in when physiological responses and emotions occur.

The Schachter-Singer two-factor theory of emotion and the cognitive-mediational theory are relatively more difficult to understand, not only because they are more complicated, but also sometimes it is difficult to distinguish between cognitive label and appraisal.

The Schachter-Singer two-factor theory asserts that two factors are necessary for a particular emotion: a high enough level of physical arousal and cognitive arousal that changes physiological state. In fact, emotional states are the result of the integration of cognitive processes, physiological states, and environmental factors in the cerebral cortex.

The cognitive-mediational theory firstly asserts that the stimulus situation does not directly determine emotion. From the emergence of stimulus to the generation of emotion, the process of emotion is stimulus situationassessmentemotion. Also, the production of emotion is the result of the coordination of the cerebral cortex and subcortical structures.

As can be seen from the above, the Schachter-Singer two-factor theory and the cognitive-mediational theory both have cognition component in the cerebral cortex, but the cognitive-mediational theory suggests that subcortical structures also play a role in the process of emotion.

nodes.title: The Fight or Flight Response (Emma Wong)
nodes.description: The following will provide an overview of the fight-or-flight response and how the body responds to fear.

typeData.textContent:
First described by Walter Bradford Cannon, the fight-or-flight response is an acute stress response manifesting itself as a physiological reaction that occurs in response to a perceived harmful event, attack, or threat to survival. Our fear reaction starts in the brain and spreads through the body to better prepare us to either stay and fight or flee, hence fight-or-flight. The amygdala, a small region in the brain containing numerous nuclei, is the starting point for our fear response (OpenStax, 2018). In the presence of a threat stimulus, the amygdala is triggered, resulting in the activation of areas and systems involved in our fight-or-flight response, including the sympathetic nervous system, and the release of stress hormones. 

Common physiological responses to fear stimuli include: increased heart rate, increased breathing rate, increased blood pressure, dilated pupils, pale or flushed skin, loss of bladder or bowel control, a compromise in the blunt pain response, and trembling (OpenStax, 2018). According to Cherry (2019), an increase in the breathing and heart rate occurs in order to provide the body with the oxygen needed to rapidly respond to any threat. The pupils dilate in order to allow more light into the eye, resulting in better vision of the surroundings. The pale or flushed skin is due to the reduced flow of blood to surface areas of the body while the flow to the muscles, brain, legs and arms is increased. The last of the common physiological responses to fear is trembling, which indicates that our bodies are primed for action. 

The autonomic nervous system, broken into the sympathetic nervous system and the parasympathetic nervous system, supplies the internal organs. While the parasympathetic nervous system is responsible for homeostasis and works to relax the body and conserve and restore energy, the sympathetic nervous system is responsible for our fight-or-flight response (OpenStax, 2018). There are multiple physiological reactions that arise due to the perception of a threat stimulus, including increased heart rate, increased breathing rate, and more. 


References
Cherry, K. (2019, August 18). The Fight-or-Flight Response Prepares Your Body to Take Action. 
         Retrieved July 06, 2020, from https://www.verywellmind.com/ 
         what-is-the-fight-or-flight-response-2795194
OpenStax, Psychology. OpenStax CNX. Oct 31, 2018.

nodes.title: What Makes an Emotion Basic? (Lang Kuoch)
nodes.description: A Deeper Look at Paul Ekmans 7 Universal Basic Emotions

typeData.textContent:
Anger, fear, surprise, sadness, disgust, contempt, and happiness: what do all these emotions have in common? Well, to most people the answer may not be so obvious. Whats so unique to these emotions that embarrassment or guilt do not share? 

To Ekman, the answer is obvious. He says that the adjective basic, when used to describe emotions, embodies two main characteristics. One is that the emotions are discrete, that they can be distinguished fundamentally from one another. The second characteristic is the view that emotions have evolved through adaptation to our surroundings. This means that, although we have an ability to handle a wealth of cognitive load, our biological mechanisms are specified to react to fundamental life tasks like losses, frustrations, successes, and joys. Each emotion, in response to these experiences, prompts us in a direction that, over evolution, has done better than other solutions in recurring circumstances that are relevant to our goals.

So now we have a better idea of what caused rise to these basic emotions. But we still havent answered our original question: how do you distinguish basic from nonbasic emotions? To start, we need to understand the dichotomy at hand. An emotion is either basic, or it is another affective phenomenon saturated with (but different from) the emotions, such as a mood, an emotional trait, and emotional disorder. For example, guilt cannot be considered a basic emotion because it is uncertain whether it has a distinctive signal different from the family of signals for the basic emotion of sadness. To determine what constitutes a basic emotion, Ekman has devised a set of 13 characteristics that he thinks is found in most (if not nearly all) of them. These are:

1. Distinctive universal signals. 
2. Distinctive physiology. 
3. Automatic appraisal. 
4. Distinctive universals in antecedent events. 
5. Presence in other primates. 
6. Capable of quick onset. 
7. Can be of brief duration. 
8. Unbidden occurrence. 
9. Distinctive thoughts, memories, and images. 
10. Distinctive subjective experience. 
11. Refractory period filters information available to what supports the emotion. 
12. Target of emotion unconstrained. 
13. The emotion can be enacted in either a constructive or destructive fashion.

So, whats the difference between basic emotions and other affective states? Take cheerful as an example. A high incidence of happiness-related signals over a certain period of time can suggest a cheerful emotional trait. So why isnt cheerful its own basic emotion? Well, cheerfulness does not have a signal different from those evident in the happiness ones, so we cant call being cheerful a basic emotion.

In short, the basic emotions ae discrete physiological responses to fundamental life situations that have been useful in our ancestral environment. These responses are universally shared within our species; the basic emotions are not learned from our culture or environment, but rather they are prewired response to a set of stimuli that have affect our species for hundreds of thousands of years.

Works Cited

Paul Ekman, D. C. (2011). What is Meant by Calling Emotions Basic. Emotion Review, 364-370. DOI: 10.1177/1754073911410740

nodes.title: The Effects of a Duchenne Smile on the Body (John Sastrillo)

typeData.textContent:
Many muscles are involved to create a smile. Though this may be the case, there are 2 muscles that distinguish a Duchenne Smile from others which are the zygomatic major and the orbicularis oculi. Beyond these muscles, we also see that a fake smile versus a real smile comes from different parts in the brain. The Duchenne smile comes from the limbic part of the brain which controls several emotions where as a fake smile would come from the motor cortex.

Even though weve seen that smiling more may have an effect in our overall mood (OpenStax 2018), there may even be a difference in how effective Duchenne smiles versus fake smailes can effect our overall mood. Keltner and Bonanno in 1997 found that those who had a genuine smile during hard times, in this case people discussing recently deceased wives, had a lower levels of distress.

nodes.title: The Theory of Constructed Emotion by Lisa Feldman (Psyched - Rachel Wong)

typeData.textContent:
We understand that emotions is expressed by physiological responses in the body, whether that be sweating before a job interview, increase in heart rate when watching a horror film, and gagging when sniffing the spoiled milk from the fridge. However, some of these responses may not be very obvious to the people around you. As emotion is said to be a nonverbal way to communicate one's thoughts and feelings, the other, more obvious, form is through body language. 

Body language refers to the nonverbal signals we use to communicate. This could be facial expressions, hand gestures, posture, and other physical cue of how the person is thinking and/or feeling. Body language registers almost immediately to the brain and often happens unconsciously. Due to its unconscious registration, body language is the most telling cues as to what the person is thinking and feeling. So how exactly is body language expressed? These are some things to look for when trying to interpret someone's body language: 

Facial Expression 
This is a telling one as when you're communicating with a person, you're often speaking to their face. In some cases, one's facial expression can give away a person's true feelings in a given situation despite them saying otherwise. The expression on someone's face can also help a person determine whether or not the individual, of whom they are speaking to, is trustworthy or not. Although, there have been studies that say that facial expressions can easily be manipulated by the person wearing them so, at times, the expression you see may not be the true feelings of that person. 

The Eyes
Being "the windows to the soul", the eyes have the ability to reveal the true feelings and thoughts of a person. An example being a person's eye gaze, whether they are looking directly in your eyes while having the conversation or breaking eye contact and frequently looking away. Direct eye contact can indicate that they person is genuinely interested and paying attention to the conversation while frequent diverting of eye contact could indicate distraction and/or an attempt to conceal their true feelings on the matter. 

The Mouth 
Mouth expressions and movements when listening or speaking can be essential in body language. One of the most telling expressions would be a smile, however a smile may be genuine or it could also express false happiness, sarcasm, and even cynicism. 

Posture
An individual's posture can be a wealth of information, not only of how a person's feeling, but also cues of their personality characteristics. An example being that an open posture would convey confidence, friendliness, openness, and attentiveness. While a closed posture would convey indifference, unfriendliness, anxiety, boredom, and hostility. 

Personal Space
The physical space between individuals as they interact can convey the relationship between the individuals. Anthropologist Edward T. Hall asserts that there are four levels of distance that happen in certain social scenarios. 

Intimate Distance: 6 to 18 inches
This level indicates intimacy between the two individuals and a close relationship. Usually is accompanied with other forms of contact such as hugging and other forms of touching. 

Personal Distance: 1.5 feet to 4 feet
This level usually occurs between family members or close friends. 

Social Distance: 4 to 12 feet
This level usually indicates individuals who are acquaintances; a closer distance would be with someone who you know fairly well and am somewhat comfortable with while the further distance would be someone you do not know so well. 

Public Distance: 12 to 25 feet
This level of physical distance is often seen in public speaking situations like making a presentation in front of a class of students or performing in front of an audience. 

Of course, public space is relative in terms of culture. Some cultures value one's personal space, while others prefer to stand closer to one another when communicating. 

Understanding and recognizing these certain cues of nonverbal communication can not only help assess a person's true feelings and thoughts, but also be able to expertly convey your own feelings with body language.

nodes.title: A Higher-Order Theory of Emotional Consciousness (Mikayla Poloz)

typeData.textContent:
While emotions and feelings are a significant part of our life, there has been comparably little connections between theories of emotion and emerging theories of consciousness. Emotional feelings are traditionally seen as being innately programmed in subcortical areas of the brain. This is shown in Darwin's Theory of the Evolution of Emotion, as particular emotional responses tend to accompany the same emotional states in a species. However, emotional states of consciousness and cognitive states of consciousness, such as those related to the perception of external stimuli, are often treated differently. Using a modified version of what is known as the higher-order theory of consciousness, it is argued that although subcortical circuits are not directly responsible for conscious feelings, they contribute nonconscious inputs that merge with other neural signals in the cognitive formation of conscious emotional experiences. 

Within the higher-order theory of consciousness, in addition to having a representation of a stimulus, one must also be aware of that stimulus representation. The idea that subcortical circuits control innate behaviours, and related physiological responses, is built upon, and through cognitive processing in cortical areas, introspectively accessible experiences emerge. A visual threat, such as a bear at your campsite, is processed in two sets of circuits in parallel in the process of giving rise to a feeling of fear. It is concluded that the construction of emotions is more about process and less about structure. Therefore, it is asserted that both emotional and non-emotional conscious experiences arise from a general cortical network of cognition, essential for all experiences. 



References 
Emotions as higher-order states of consciousness
Joseph E. LeDoux, Richard Brown
Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences Mar 2017, 114 (10) E2016-E2025; DOI: 10.1073/pnas.161931611

nodes.title: Kohlberg's Theory of Moral Development (Halie Yelle)
The Power of Body Language (Adrianna Liang)
Primary and Secondary Emotions (Psyched12- Aman Padda)

typeData.textContent:
Primary emotions are our universal emotions. They are direct emotional reactions to a situation, that are easy to understand. The seven primary emotions are happiness, sadness, surprise, fright, disgust, anger, and contempt.

However, we dont always know or show what we feel. You might experience unwanted feelings, or feelings that you have been taught not to express. This is when you usually encounter your secondary emotions. A secondary emotion is an emotional response to a primary emotion, thus an emotion about what you feel. A few examples of secondary emotions include guilt, shame, and confusion.

* Secondary emotions increase the intensity of your reactions. 
* They tend to stick around for a longer period of time compared to primary emotions. 
* They can also become problematicbecause they can potentially "take over" from primary emotions, effectively blocking them. 

-Differentiating Between Primary and Secondary Emotions

Differentiating between primary and secondary emotions provides powerful coping skills.

Questions to ask yourself to help you differentiate:

1. Is this emotion a direct reaction to an external event?    Primary
2. Is the emotion becoming more intense over time?     Secondary
3. Do you experience the emotion more frequently than the events that prompted the emotion?     Secondary
4. When the initiating event receded, did the emotions recede?     Primary
5. Does the emotion continue long after the event, interfere with your abilities in the present, and affect new and different experiences?     Secondary
6. Is the emotion complex, ambiguous, and difficult to understand?     Secondary

nodes.title: Limbic System and Mood Disorders (Anna Malikovskaia, psyched12)
nodes.description: The amygdala and the hippocampus are associated with various mood and anxiety disorders

typeData.textContent:
Both the amygdala and the hippocampus that are parts of limbic system were found to be linked with mood and anxiety disorders. According to animal research done by Raneki, Corts, Belnoue, and Sullivan, rat pups that were exposed to abuse during postnatal age were more likely to show depressive-like symptoms later in adolescence. Moreover, these rats had increased amygdala activity. Another research done by Moriceau and Sullivan also showed that there is increased activation of the amygdala in rat pups that had learned to fear odor cue that was paired with electrical shock. This was true for the pups left alone without mother. In the presence of mother, however, the pups showed preference for the odor and normal activity of amygdala. This experiment implies that there is a differential effect on the amygdala by the context. Several human researches support the idea of abnormalities in the amygdala activity in individuals with various mood or anxiety disorders. 
Studies also demonstrated that there is a link between hippocampus structure and function and mood and anxiety disorders. More specifically, several regions of the hippocampus were found to be smaller in volume than normal in individuals with posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD). Furthermore, cognitive-behavioral or medical treatment in individuals with PSTD showed improvements in both behaviour and hippocampal volume.

nodes.title: Schachter-Singer Two-Factor Theory of Emotion to Describe Acute Pain (Raymond Wong)

typeData.textContent:
Schachter-Singer two-factor theory of emotion incorporates the physiological arousal and subjective experiences from a stimulus that produce an emotional response. These emotional responses are typically influenced by three components: physiological arousal, psychological appraisal and subjective experiences. For example, an individual was lifting a heavy object, when they suddenly felt a sharp pain in their lower back. A typical physiological response would be the release of stress hormones from the sympathetic division of the autonomic nervous system. At the same time, when inspecting the injury, they notice that rotating their torso reproduces the same perception of pain, which leads them to think they may have severely injured themselves. This in-turn triggers an emotional response that leads to fear.

The SchachterSinger two-factor theory
(SchachterSinger Theory of Emotion (Two-Factor Theory), 2016.)
Furthermore, individual differences in psychological appraisal of a given situation and prior subjective experiences could affect the degree to which individuals respond emotionally to a stimulus since they are informed by individual experiences, backgrounds, and cultures. More specifically, individuals who catastrophize painful situations, which is a complex psychological process in which an individual appraises a situation in a excessively negative and maladaptive way (Koechlin, Coakley, Schechter, Werner, & Kossowsky, 2018). Going back to the previous example, if the same individual, who in the past has catastrophized previous acute injuries, would most likely experience a greater negative emotional response (Koechlin et al., 2018). Moreover, the negative psychological assessment by the catastrophizing individual coupled with their previous negative experiences with acute injuries would likely lead to a greater perception of pain due to the heighten negative emotional response (Koechlin et al., 2018). In comparison, if the same individual with a neutral psychological appraisal and who does not catastrophize their injury would likely produce a lower negative emotional response and be in less pain despite similar injuries (Koechlin et al., 2018).

References

Koechlin, H., Coakley, R., Schechter, N., Werner, C., & Kossowsky, J. (2018). The role of emotion regulation in chronic pain: A systematic literature review. Journal of psychosomatic research, 107, 38-45.

SchachterSinger Theory of Emotion (Two-Factor Theory). (2016). [Illustration]. Boundless.Com. http://oer2go.org/mods/en-boundless/www.boundless.com/psychology/textbooks/boundless-psychology-textbook/emotion-13/theories-of-emotion-410/schachter-singer-theory-of-emotion-two-factor-theory-507-16764/index.html

nodes.title: Jean Piaget's Theory of Development (Claudia Le)
nodes.description: After spending many years studying childhood development, Jean Piaget developed a theory that explained how children's cognitive abilities went through specific stages.

typeData.textContent:
While there were many theories that focused on how children developed, Jean Piaget specifically focused on how they developed cognitively. Piaget viewed growth as discontinuous since he believed children's cognitive abilities took place in stages rather than improving on pre existing skills. 

As children grew, they developed schemata, concepts that helped them understand and organize information that they learned. When learning, children were to adjust schemata through assimilation or accomodation. Assimilation was incorporating new information comparable to our existing knowledge while accomodation was when children modified their schemata based on new experiences or information. 

Piaget said that there was 4 stages of cognitive development people went through: sensorimotor, preoperational, concrete operational, and formal operational. 

Sensorimotor lasted from birth to 2 years old. In this first stage, children are experiencing the world through their senses and actions. Children also develop object permanence in this stage, the act of understanding that if an object cannot be sensed, it still exists. Piaget also believed that babies develop stranger anxiety in this stage.

The next stage was the preoperational stage which lasted from the ages of 2 to 7 years old. While a child may have finally developed the ability to use words and pictures to to represent things, they lack logical reasoning for it. Children have yet to also understand the concept of conservation, they would likely think that if a jug of water was poured into two glasses, that there would be more water. Additionally, children will display egocentrism. Their logic is based on their own personal experiences, therefore, they think that everyone feels the same way as they do. 

The third stage Piaget introduced was called the concrete operational stage. Occurring from 7 to 11 years old, children are able to logically understand concepts and expected to perform basic mathematical transformations. They now understand conservation and reversibility as well, where objects can return back to their original form. 

The last stage lasts from 11 years old to adulthood. The formal operational stage explains that children are now able to think and understand abstract ideas. They develop the ability for moral reasoning and a renewed egocentrism may occur where adolescents fixate on something that others will not notice. 

Similar to many other theories, Piaget's theory of development has also come under criticism. Other studies believed that childhood development was more continuous, building on existing skills rather than taking place in different stages. Additionally, others thought that there was a fifth stage known as the postformal stage. In this stage, decisions were made based on context and logic is integrated with emotion to solve problems.

nodes.title: Piaget's Theory of Cognitive Development (BADGER102 - ERICA WON)

typeData.textContent:
I will be discussing schemata and the assimilation and accommodation of information.

A schemata is a concept that helps people categorize and interpret information. In order to learn new things, you can either assimilate new knowledge or accommodate your schema.

For example, a child grows up with a dog by her side. This dog is the only mammal she knows. It has 4 legs, and is incredibly furry and warm. Overtime, she has assimilated new knowledge into her schemata. Now she knows that dogs have 4 legs, fur, and warmth.

She then sees a cat for the first time ever! She notices that it also has 4 legs, fur, and warmth.

Despite the visual differences between a dog and a cat, the child proceeds to call the cat a dog, because she hasnt learned to differentiate between the two in her schema. In the same way we would call dogs and cats mammals, shes assuming that both dogs and cats are dogs because of similar traits (4 legs, fur, warmth).

Understanding a Schema in Psychology
Her dad tells her No, thats not a dog. Its a cat. It has a different body shape, different ears, and makes a different sound. Now, the little child has accommodated her schemata to differentiate between dogs and cats. Dogs go woof and cats go meow.

Additionally, schema bias can occur where ones beliefs are resistant to change and influence ones ability/willingness to accommodate new information. This results in prejudice, where one chooses NOT to accept the new information because it doesnt fit with their schema.

This can result in stereotypes and discrimination based on those stereotypes.

Schema Bias | Schema
In the photo above, we see how this person accepts information that is consistent with the schema.

For example, the 3rd picture shows of someone who has recently had an argument with their boyfriend. Because they heavily believe that they are unloveable, this piece of information reinforces that belief. Unfortunately, the fact that theyve been dating for 5 years nor the fact that a colleague came to visit them in the hospital doesnt matter, because this person is focusing on what fits her beliefs.

It is very important to recognize schema bias and address it accordingly. Ones negative outlook on life can be very detrimental to their mental health. Similarly, ones perception of a race/age/gender can lead to discrimination and unnecessary violence.

nodes.title: Newborn Reflexes and Depth Perception (Harleen Rattan)
nodes.description: This node teaches students more about innate newborn reflexes and what depth perception is.

typeData.textContent:
Newborn reflexes are automatic responses to particular forms of stimulation. The unique part about these reflexes is that they were never taught to the babies, they are innate.  Some of the reflexes that babies are born with include rooting, sucking, grasping, and moro. Elaborating on the sucking reflex, babies know that they need to use their mouths to suck in order to get milk. Imagine if babies did not know how to suckthey would feel hungry all the time as they wouldn't be able to know how to drink milk. 
Another interesting ability that children later develop is depth perception. Depth perception is the ability to see the world in 3D dimensions. Similar to newborn reflexes, depth perception in innate (partly), meaning that children are not taught it, they develop it themselves. The rest of it is developed by experience. 
An experiment called the visual cliff experiment was created in order to test the depth perception in children. In this experiment, a heavy Plexiglas is placed a foot more off the floor. One side of this glass is covered by a patterned fabric which makes the glass appear solid. The same fabric is placed on the floor below the glass; making it appear as if it were a cliff (Cherry, 2020). The child is then placed onto the glass and the childs caregiver stands on the other end of the glass (the side that appears as a cliff). If the child had developed depth perception, it would be reluctant to crawl towards the caregiver as it thinks it would fall into the cliff. On the other hand, if the child lacked depth perception, it would happily crawl towards the caregiver despite the cliff in front of it (Cherry, 2020). 
I encourage you to watch this YouTube link to learn more about this experiment: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DrzmvI6iMrE
