nodes.title: Stage 4: Industry vs. Inferiority (Michael Waters)
nodes.description: This node provides a brief overview of Erikson's fourth stage of development, Industry vs. Inferiority.

typeData.textContent:
The psychosocial theory of development is a theory which was created by Erik Erikson in an attempt to figure out how humans develop into adults. Erikson was a stage theorist which means that he believed that development occurs in stages and is therefore discontinous. With his psychosocial theory,  he focused on the social aspect of our development and believed that in each stage of a human's life there is a psychosocial task that we must master in order to feel competent. Erikson also believed that development was an event that occurred throughout the entire lifespan of a human. 

       Erikson proposed that there are eight stages of development during our lifespan, each with a task at hand to complete. Here, I will go through each of the eight stages briefly to give an idea of the tasks that are present at the various stages. 

     In stage 1, trust vs mistrust is our developmental task and this occurs from birth to twelve months of age. Here, if infants are treated with attention and sensitivity from their caregivers, they will see the world as a safe place, whereas if an infant was treated poorly they may look at the world negatively as an unsafe environment. Stage 2 occurs during the ages 1-3, and this focuses on the task of autonomy vs shame. If a toddler is able to perform a task independently, they will feel a positive sense of independence, but if they are denied the chance of being able to perform independently, they will feel ashamed in themselves and develop a lack of self esteem. 

         Stage 3 occurs from ages 3-6 and the task is initiative vs guilt. In this stage, one will feel a sense of guilt if they are unable to be successful in a situation where they are taking initiative, but if they succeed, they will develop confidence. Stage 4 occurs from ages 7-11 and here the task is industry vs inferiority. In this stage, if one is competent, they will feel confident whereas if they are not they will develop a sense of inferiority. Stage 5 occurs from ages 12-18 and the task at hand is identity vs confusion. Here the task is to develop a sense of self, and so those that are successful in this task will feel a good sense of identity, whereas those who are not will be confused and feel unsure of their identity.

        Stage 6 occurs from ages 19-29 and here there is a task of intimacy vs isolation, where if one is unable to be intimate they will develop a very lonely feeling. Stage 7 occurs from ages 30-64 and the task is generativity vs stagnation. One will feel like they are in a state of stagnation if they do not succeed in tasks that contribute to the development of others such as raising children or volunteering. And lastly, stage 8 occurs from the ages of 65 to the end of life where the task is integrity vs dispair where people who feel proud of their accomplishments of their life as they are looking back will develop a sense of integrity, but if one looks back at their life with regrets about what they should have done they will develop a sense of dispair. 

     According to Erikson, through the completion of each task, one will develop a healthy personality and a good sense of competence. Negatively, if one fails to complete a task they will develop a feeling that they are inadequate.

Authoritative vs Authoritarian parenting style (Isaaca Wang)

typeData.textContent:
Is the Authoritative parenting style the ideal parenting style?

The psychosocial and emotional development of children is influenced by
their caregivers' parenting styles. The formation of a child's self-concept is
often shaped by whether their parents exercise an Authoritarian, Authoritative,
Permissive, or Uninvolved parenting style. Although the Authoritative parenting
style is accepted as the ideal parenting style in Western society, the
Authoritarian style of parenting can be just as effective - with respect to
certain conditions. This piece of writing will explore the complex nature of
the Authoritarian parenting style, a parenting style often externalized as the
disciplinary practices of guilt induction, love withdrawal, or a combination of
both. Guilt induction is evoking the feeling of guilt by personalizing the consequences
of the child's behavior in an attempt to change that behavior. Love withdrawal
involves manipulating feelings of acceptance as a sign of disapproval by
withholding friendliness, warmth, and/or attention, indicating to the child
that they are loved only if they comply to their parents demands.

A recent study aimed to discover whether there is a correlation between the usage guilt induction/love withdrawal and a tendency for the affected child to engage in bullying behaviors at school (Yu, Cheah, Hart, Yang, & Olsen, 2019). The population demographic that this research examines is 133 first-generation Chinese American mothers and their preschool children. In the experimental procedure, preschool teachers rated the childrens frequency of bullying behaviors on a five-point scale based on various means of assessment, such as kicks other children for the sake of it and makes fun of peers possessions. Using the same measurement scale, the mothers rated the frequency of their usage of guilt induction and love withdrawal. The researchers then used the data to calculate the degree of correlation between the two variables. The results show no salient effects of guilt induction on bullying but do show negative effects of love withdrawal on social aggression. This illustrates the negative consequences of the disciplinary practice of love withdrawal; during which the parent appears to stop loving their child. Although the parent, in most cases, does continue to love the child, the child does not perceive it as such; thus, it is unclear to the child that the parent unconditionally loves them. This form of psychological assault not only jeopardizes the parent-child relationship but contributes to various forms of maladjustment during childhood, including the aggressive bullying behaviors exemplified in this study. Guilt induction, however, did not affect the Chinese American children in the study. Interestingly, in individualistic cultures like the US, guilt induction may be felt as parental rejection or lack of parental support. Accordingly, it would hinder positive development in European-American children. However, in collectivist cultures like many Asian cultures, children often interpret guilt induction as concern and caring for their well-being on the part of the parent instead of parental rejection; this is due to being raised in a cultural context that emphasizes a more interconnected sense of self. As such, whether an Authoritarian parenting style is effective or not depends on ethnicity/culture and the disciplinary practices employed. Children of certain Asian ethnicities whose parents did not use love withdrawal usually undergo a healthy emotional development and the formation of a positive self-concept, thus dispelling the popular conception that the Authoritative parenting style is the universally ideal parenting style.

Yu, J., Cheah, C. S. L., Hart, C. H., Yang, C., & Olsen, J. A. (2019). Longitudinal effects of maternal love withdrawal and guilt induction on Chinese American preschoolers bullying aggressive behavior.Development and Psychopathology,31(04), 14671475. doi: 10.1017/s0954579418001049

nodes.title: Identity Formation and Toxic Masculinity (Nathan Cottell; Group: fernathan)

typeData.textContent: This course has shown how both Erikson and Marcia believed that identity formation, particularly during adolescence, is critical to psychological fitness. I think it is important to consider the intersection of gender norms with the stages of identity formation identified by these theorists. For many adolescents assigned male at birth in western cultures, the state of identity diffusion or moratorium described by Marcia can leave a person more vulnerable to the formation of toxic masculine behaviours such as emotional repression or misogyny. These behaviours have been reinforced by depictions in media for hundreds of years. In the next node, you can listen to a recording of me performing a monologue from Shakespeare's Much Ado about Nothing, written in the early 1600s. Check out how the speaker, Benedick, ridicules his good friend Claudio for being emotionally expressive and for having interests which diverge from traditional, martial, masculine ones. Benedick also has some very dismissive and misogynist views about women.

nodes.description: This node will cover Marcia's 4 identity statuses and follow up on previous nodes content.

typeData.textContent:
Continuing on Nathans node, I will be expanding on Marcias findings and theories.

James Marcia, a theorist inspired by Eriksons beliefs of identity formation, crisis and confusion, worked on a theory primarily focussing on the relationship between an individuals goals and commitment with respect to their identity. Marcia would then separate four main points of his theory into identity statuses and this would be used to differentiate developmental identity points possible in an individuals life. 

1.	Identity Diffusion  When an individual lacks commitment or exploration to an ideology/identity

2.	Identity Foreclosure  When an individual presents a high level of commitment but often lacks exploration in other ideologies

3.	Identity Moratorium  When an individual presents a high level of exploration but lacks commitment to any identity/ideology

4.	Identity Achievement  When an individual presents both a high level of commitment and exploration and decides on an identity/ideology to stand by

Following up on Nathans example of toxic masculinity and emotional repression, we can create an example on how it may relate to one of the previously mentioned stages being identity diffusion. For our imaginary individual Bob, he is considered to be in the first identity status and stays at home without knowing a purpose in what to do with his life. His strict father Joe, who is home all the time thanks to COVID, is infuriated anytime he sees Bob slacking off and goes off on a vocal rampage whenever Bob speaks. Because of this, Bob is uncomfortable and tries to show little to no emotion in hopes or his father to speak nicer to him and hide his pain from the verbal abuse.

If an individual (such as Bob) is under the identity diffusion stage, it is likely that the individual is avoidant to discomfort and seeks pleasure and comfort. 

Now creating an example on the same topic as before, this time in the identity moratorium stage described by Nathans node. Imagine Bob going around the city and applying for any job available on the block and coming home with news of his progress. His father with his vocal fury replies with a statement challenging his goals and future for the 457th time. At this point Bob fully represses his feelings and emotions towards his father and begins to have feelings of confusion and self-doubt, delaying any commitment as he thinks about his choices.

This is just an example and fictional, with the focus on parental influence and Bobs seeking adventure for his fathers approval of Bobs identity.

Little Hans Case Study (Heyden Lam, HEH24)

typeData.textContent:
Little Hans was a 5-year-old boy that had a phobia of horses. A prominent event that marked his phobia was when he saw a horse fall down when it was carrying a heavy cart. Hans said this experience was frightening because he dislikes the sound of horses falling down and their hooves clattering against the concrete. Another event that seems to connect with Hans fear of horses was when he was 3 years old (during the phallic stage of the psychosexual development stages), he had a strong interest in his own widdler (penis) and those of others. His mother told him to stop touching his widdler or else she would ask a doctor to cut it off. Sigmund Freud, a popular psychologist at the time found Hans case very interesting and decided to help him overcome his fear.

Due to Hans fear of horses, he developed an anxiety of going out of his house because they lived across a busy coaching inn and many horses were around the area. When Hans was asked which specific type of horses he was afraid of, he provided a very detailed answer. Hans disliked white horses with black bits around their mouths that wear blinkers. Additionally, Hans father had more in-depth conversations with Hans and discovered that Hans was afraid that a horse will bite off his widdler and this fear was somehow connected to being frightened by the sight of a large penis. From these sets of information, Freud realized that the horses Hans was afraid of is actually his father. Hans was scared that his father would castrate him for having incestuous desires towards his mother. The characteristics of the horses that Hans disliked were actually his fathers, as he has pale skin, a moustache and wears glasses. 

Freud diagnosed Hans with Oedipus complex, where a child develops sexual desires for the opposite-sex parent and becomes jealous of the same-sex parent for receiving affection from the other parent. Oedipus complex occurs during the phallic stage of psychosexual development, between the ages of 3 and 6. The fear that the father might find out his son has sexual feelings towards the mother often leads to castration anxiety, which is the fear that the father will cut off the sons penis. In order to manage this anxiety, the son will likely start adopting the fathers behaviour, attitudes, and values to prevent conflicts from arising. This behaviour is also known as identification with the aggressor. Oedipus complex can be mostly resolved by having the father directly tell his son that he does not want to castrate him.

typeData.textContent:
A cohort is basically a group of people who have shared a particular event together during a particular time span.The most commonly studied cohorts are age-related. Examples included people sharing the same birthday, growing up in the same region during the same time period and also people who were exposed to the same natural disaster.
A cohort effect is a research result that occurs because of the characteristics of the cohort being studied. Cohort effects are important to take into account in research. Cohort effects can compromise the results of research that uses cross-sectional methods. Even longitudinal design may have cohort effects. They are important in developmental studies because they can be confounding variables.
In order to determine whether a cohort effect is present, a researcher may conduct a cohort study.A cohort study is a particular form of longitudinal study that samples a cohort performing a cross-section at intervals through time. 

References:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cohort_study
https://www.thoughtco.com/cohort-effect-definition-4582483

linkMetadata.description: Piagets last stage is known as the Formal Operational Stage. At this stage, individuals can logically solve abstract ideas and solve them with hypothetical solutions or find alternative solutions and test them out. In adolescence, there is a renewed sense of egocentrism, however, it is not similar to the one perceived during the preoperational stage. This is where the adolescent believes their flaws are much larger due to their interpretation of public perception but in reality, it is not.

Week 7: Freuds Psychosexual Theory of Development (Shawn Yee)
nodes.description: A deeper look into Freud's psychosexual theory of development, briefly mentioned in the lectures but never expanded on.

typeData.textContent:
A springboard for Eriksons psychosocial theory of development was Freuds psychosexual theory of development, with five main stages, in a specific order: oral, anal, phallic, latency, and genital. Freuds main thesis was that children go through these stages of development that ultimately coalescence into ones personality. In this case, the -sexual suffix used by Freud was more broadly defined as activities which resulted in pleasure. Any over-stimulation or under-stimulation, referred to as overindulgence and frustration respectively in any stage would result in fixation in that particular stage, which would eventually lead to certain abnormalities in ones personality.

The first main stage described by Freud is the oral stage, ranging from birth to around 2 years of age. During this phase, the main source of pleasure is derived form orally related activities, such as thumb-sucking and breast feeding. If a person were to become fixated in this stage, behaviours such as alcoholism, smoking, and other orally related activities would arise later in life.

This pattern continues for the next few stages. In the anal stage, from around age 2 to 3, where the child gains pleasure from defecating. An overindulgence in his stage may result in overly messy or disorganized lifestyles, while a frustration may result in an obsession with cleanliness.

In the phallic stage, from ages 3 to 6, a child would begin to start desiring their opposite-sex parent, which would eventually lead to either castration anxiety for males or penis envy in females. This is resolved with a process referred to as identification, where male children start to act and behave like their fathers and females adopt the female gender role based on their mothers. Fixations on this stage may lead to a weak sense of sexual identity in the future.

From ages 6 to puberty, the child undergoes a latency stage, where all pleasurable desires are repressed in favour of socialization with other peers, particularly those of the same sex, sharing hobbies and interests.

Finally, in the genital stage, which begins from puberty onwards, the teenagers desire once again turns to members of the opposite sex, and eventually develop into functioning members of society with the desire to procreate and ensure the survival of humanity.    

Obviously, there are some major criticisms surrounding Freuds psychosexual theory of development, and one of the most prominent ones is that his theory is unfalsifiable, a trait which is necessary in any scientific theory. Some additions criticisms include the heteronormativity especially present in the phallic and genital stages, as well as possibly implying that children of single-parent households may develop abnormal personalities. However, despite these criticisms, one undisputed fact is that Freuds theories contributed majorly to the field of psychology, and his theories have also been a stepping stone for other, more scientific theories including Eriksons.

Works Consulted:

Felluga, D. (2011, January 11). Introductory Guide to Critical Theory. Purdue U. http://www.purdue.edu/guidetotheory/psychoanalysis/freud.html

McLeod, S. A. (2019, July 18). Psychosexual stages. Simply Psychology. https://www.simplypsychology.org/psychosexual.html

Psychology Notes HQ. (2020, February 14). Sigmund Freuds Psychosexual Theory. https://www.psychologynoteshq.com/freud-psychosexual-development/

The Effects of Parenting Styles and Childhood Attachment Patterns (Psyched12- Aman Padda)

typeData.textContent:
The type of attachment that a child forms has long-term repercussions into many aspects of the child's development and adult life. Some of these aspects include peer relationships and the ability to maintain long-term intimate relationships. 

Persons with secure childhood attachments show higher levels of trust, closeness, and dependability while insecure childhood attachments predict the reverse.

 The authoritative parent is sensitive to the child's needs, does not use punitive discipline, and reasons with the child in a loving and affectionate manner. This type of parenting is usually found to form secure attachment styles in children. 

Comparatively, the authoritarian parent is demanding, but unresponsive to the child, tends to use punitive and harsh punishment, physical enforcement, reprimands, and prohibitive interventions. The outcomes of authoritarian parenting tend to overlap the characteristics of avoidant attachment. The children of authoritarian parents have been described as anxious, angry, aggressive, and having low self-esteem.

Permissive parents make few demands and rarely use punishment. They tend to be very nurturing and loving, and may play the role of friend rather than parent. Children of permissive parents have low self-control and self-reliance, and are very immature.

Impact of Autism on Children Development (Psyched12 - Rachel Wong)

typeData.textContent: Autism Spectrum Disorder is a developmental disorder that affects an individuals social skill, communication skills, and behavior towards certain situations. Autism is generally discovered at a young age. The signs are telling as a childs development differ from the norms. Some signs include being unresponsive to their name, social isolation from other children, repetitive behavior (flapping their hands or rocking their body), avoiding eye contact, etc. This disorder causes a child to develop at a different rate and order than other children. It affects a childs joint attention; using eye contact and gestures to express themselves with others. This poses a challenge with the childs ability to successful communicate with others, including the parents, as well as language skills. Often, children on the Autism spectrum is unable to create a relation between the a word of an object with a picture of the object; example, they would not make the connection of a picture of a dog with the word dog. The inability to process joint attention can hinder a childs capacity to learn certain skills like taking turns, reading facial expressions, staying with a topic of a conversation, etc. The most common and telling sign of this disorder is an individuals lack of social skills. This incompetence to interpret social cues comes from their inability to see things from other peoples perspectives; they are unable to understand and empathize with other peoples desires, feelings, and beliefs, if it so happen to be different from their own. This results in a difficulty getting along with other people as many find this behavior rude and insulting. However, the intention of the matter is never cruel, its simply due to the fact that a child suffering with ASD would not understand why a person would be upset in a given situation; they simply dont understand. Although, this disorder tends to hinder a childs development early on in their years, if the disorder is caught early, the certain gaps of knowledge and skill building can be devised to help a child understand the world around them and live with Autism.

The Development of self-concept (Anna Malikovskaia psyched12)
nodes.description: Brief summary of early development of self-concept in children

typeData.textContent: By the age of 18 months toddlers start developing a self-concept. Before that age they cannot recognize themselves in the mirror. The establishment of self-concept occurs between the ages 2-4. This means that they can label themselves with gender, cooperate with other children, have little anxiety separating from their parents. At this age children show autonomy, can initiate and complete plans. They also have difficulty sharing their possessions with others, but by the age of 4 share when asked. Children learn to identify themselves as group members as well as discover personality traits of others and themselves by the age of 6. When children start school, they start comparing themselves to their peers and also recognize that they are more skilled and knowledgeable in some areas than in others. Positive self-concept is important in the development of self-confidence. Many factors shape the development of self-concept and one of the most important is parenting style.

nodes.title: How Socioeconomic Status can Affect Child Development (Angelina Hollihn)
nodes.description: Social status can affect childhood development in terms of intelligence

typeData.textContent:
Group Name: MAA

There is research that shows a difference in IQ between individuals of higher SES and individuals of lower SES. This is known as the achievement gap, which shows a consistent gap in test scores, graduation rates, and grades. Experts believe this gap is due to the parenting difference between low and high SES families. Studies found that parents in high and middle SES families spoke more to their children. By speaking to children more, it increases their vocabulary at a younger age. This makes it easier for children to learn how to read, write, speak, and understand social cues. The IQ of an individual is based on the environment they grow up in as well as genetic factors. This is the cause of nature and nurture as we have learned in previous chapters. 

Long term poverty as well as low SES both create mental disorders and have a huge effect on mental health. A possible reason that parents in high-middle SES groups speak to their children more so than parents in lower SES groups is because they may have better mental health, as they are under less financial stress. They also may be less physically and mentally exhausted after work compared to families in lower SES groups. 

Betty Hart and Todd Risley (2006) were two psychologists who used a longitudinal study (study that uses the same variables, in this case people, over a long period of time) to learn how parents from different SES interact with their children. They found that middle and high income parents spoke to their children more, and by 3 years old the children knew nearly double the amount of words that the low income children knew. This gap became more prominent as the children aged. 

A solution for this problem that psychologists came up with is placing low SES children in schools with middle to high SES children. If children who have a smaller vocabulary are placed with children who have a larger vocabulary, this will help allow low SES children to catch up to their high SES peers. Another solution to this problem is that experts in this area of study are working in the homes of low income families, encouraging and helping parents bond and speak with their children. Other ways to help children from low income families thrive as well as children from high income families is to have them involved in community events and organizations. Such as dance classes, art classes, sport teams, summer camps. While these all cost money, there are many organizations that help fundraise for children that are less fortunate.

nodes.title: Jean Piagets Theory of Development (Angellina Holllihn)
nodes.description: Jean Piagets theory of child development is a good way to understand how parents need to

typeData.textContent:
Jean Piaget believed that there were four stages a child needed to go through in order for their cognitive abilities to function as best as possible. The four stages are sensorimotor, preoperational, concrete operational, and formal operational. The sensorimotor (0-2) stage involves gathering world experience through senses and actions, and has developmental issues with object permanence and stranger anxiety involved. The preoperational stage (ages 2-6), uses words and images to represent things, but lacks logical reasoning. This stage has developmental issues with pretend play, language development, and egocentrism. Concrete operational is the third stage (ages 7-11). This stage leads to understanding concrete events and analogies logically; ability to perform arithmetic operations. The developmental issues are conservation mathematical transformations. The last is formal operation which utilizes abstract reasoning. The developmental issues are moral reasoning. 

 Jean Piaget believed that children learn by developing schemata. Schemata are concepts (mental notes) that help them categorize objects, places, people, etc. This helps them recognize and differentiate between everything in the world around them. When children pick up new schemata and learn new information, they adjust their previous schemata through assimilation and accommodation. Assimilation is when they take in new information about the world and compare it to their previous knowledge. Accommodation is changing their previous knowledge based off of their new found information. This process happens best when children interact with their environment. However, it is not enough for the child to only be involved in the environment, the parents need to be as well. For example, let's say a child thinks that the moon is following his family in the car. He tells his parents that the moon follows them wherever they go. Because the parents are interacting with their child and the environment they are in, they can tell their child that the moon does not actually follow them. This will cause accommodation for the child's previous schemata. This needs to happen for children to learn. If a child's parents are not interacting with them, they cannot learn adequate information, and hence their IQ could be lower than its potential. As one's IQ is determined by nature and nurture, the environment one grows up in is as important as their genetics. 

Low SES families are proven to interact less with their children, resulting in their child's learning being hindered. By understanding Jean Piaget's theory of how children's cognitive development occurs, we can understand how it is necessary for parents to interact with their children at a young age for assimilation and accommodation to occur, which are both necessary for cognitive development.

typeData.textContent:
As weve seen in the past there have been several parenting styles and each one plays a role in the personalities of the child. When it comes to much younger children, weve also seen different attachment types. From research done by Doinita and Maria in 2015 attempted to find a correlation between the attachment type of the child and the parenting style of their parent.
They started with 4 hypothesis where a Secure Adult Attachment would be positively correlated with an Authoritative parenting style, Dismissing Adult Attachment would be positively correlated with an Authoritarian parenting style, Preoccupied Adult Attachment would be positively correlated with a Permissive parenting style, and a Fearful Adult Attachment would also be positively correlated with a Permissive parenting style.
	From their experiment, Doinita and Maria found that there were positive correlations between a secure adult attachment and an authoritative parenting style. Similarly, they found there was a positive correlation between a fearful adult attachment and a permissive parenting style. For the other 2 hypotheses, they found no correlation.
This follows previous ideas weve had that Authoritative parenting styles lead to a best case scenario for a childs development where they are more confident and secure in themselves. 

Citation:
Doinita, Nanu Elena, and Nijloveanu Dorina Maria. Attachment and Parenting Styles. Procedia - Social and Behavioral Sciences, vol. 203, 2015, pp. 199204., doi:10.1016/j.sbspro.2015.08.282.

nodes.title: Case Study: Cognitive Development of children with ASD - Rain Zhang

typeData.textContent:
People with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) are thought to have a specific profile of cognitive strengths and weaknesses -- difficulties appreciating others' thoughts and feelings, problems regulating and controlling their behavior, and an enhanced ability to perceive details -- but few studies have tracked children's cognitive skills over time. Now new longitudinal research provides clues that can inform our understanding of ASD.

Research conducted at Western Australia in 2010 assessed 37 children with ASD and 31 typically developing children when they were 5 to 6 years old and again three years later. The study explored the children's ability to perceive others' behavior based on their thoughts and feelings (theory of mind) by asking children to watch a series of social interactions on video and predict a character's behavior based on his or her mental state. The study then assessed the children's ability to self-regulate their behavior (executive function) by having them take part in problem-solving tasks that required them to plan ahead and show flexibility. And the study assessed children's aptitude for detecting parts of objects or small details (central coherence) by asking them to construct patterns from wooden blocks and search for shapes hidden in pictures.

The study found that children with ASD exhibited the same profile that's typically associated with ASD, both at the start of the study and three years later.  But a closer look at individual children's patterns of performance revealed that not all children with ASD displayed the same profile of cognitive strengths and weaknesses. Instead, the profiles of cognitive skills varied from one participant to the next: For example, while one child with ASD showed difficulties in theory of mind alone, another child showed problems in theory of mind plus executive function.

These findings encourage the importance of understanding the breadth of cognitive skills in children with ASD, and how these skills progress over time. A key question for the future is whether there are approaches that can facilitate progress in some of these areas.

nodes.title: Early Childhood Education and Cognitive Development (Emma Wong)
nodes.description: Discussing research conduct by Hart and Risley as well as Weikart, this node outlines the effects early childhood education has on cognitive and intellectual development.

typeData.textContent:
The argument of nature vs. nurture in regards to cognitive development, personality development, and intellectual development has spanned over decades. Research suggests that what a child experiences in their early life has a lasting impact on the development of their brain. While genes are the roadmap of our development, experiences create the neural connections that set the foundations of our emotions, language, motor skills, vision and memories.

Betty Hart and Todd Risley (2006) studied families of different socioeconomic stations to look at early language ability and progression (OpenStax 2018). While children of low-income families were exposed to an approximate 600 words per hour, children from middle- to high-income families were exposed to around 200 words ,per hour. By the age of 3, the gap becomes 30 million words (OpenStax, 2018). Additionally, Hart and Risley found that, before entering kindergarten, high-income children scored, on average, 60% higher on achievement tests than those from low-income families.

Using a longitudinal study, David Weikart and his colleagues studied the effects of pre-school education on the achievements and lifestyles of children. Weikart and his team randomly divided 123 underprivileged kids into 2 groups. One group spent 2 years in a prestigious preschool with attentive teachers while the other group did not attend such a pre-school (Sprouts, 2017). After the two years and an additional 40 years in the longitudinal study, Weikart and his team published their findings. The team found that at the age of 5, 67% of the children from the top pre-school group had an IQ greater than 90 and were school ready while only 28% of those who didnt attend were ready for school. At the age of 14, there was a large difference between basic classroom achievements. By 37, the top pre-school group was more likely to own their own home. At the age of 40, the top pre-school group was more likely to earn more money (Sprouts, 2017). Weikart and his team concluded that the 2 years in the preschool aided in cognitive and social development, teaching them attitudes (such as grit) that were useful in their later years (Sprouts, 2017).


References

OpenStax, Psychology. OpenStax CNX. Oct 31, 2018.

Sprouts. (2017, Jun 9). Early Childhood Education: The Research [Video]. Youtube. 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NNgp1_B-6c8

Lifespan Development Theories - Word Search! (Asha Khondoker)
The Creation and Comparison of the Moral Development and Cognitive Theory

typeData.textContent:
During week 7, there was a focus on different theories of lifespan development. In particular, we learned about emotional, personality and cognitive changes throughout childhood to late adulthood. It was interesting to notice how some theories piggybacked on concepts of a preceding psychologist, For example, the Moral Development Theory, created by Lawrence Kohlberg, was built upon the foundation of another theory. One of the most famous psychologists, Jean piaget, pioneered the 4 stages of development at different times in our lives, known as the Cognitive Theory of development. Both of these social psychologists focused on the childhood aspect of development, and were weary to the idea of cognitive thoughts and how they affect our behaviour. 

In the Cognitive Theory of Development, Jean Piaget proposed that there were four concrete stages. These were known as the sensorimotor, preoperational, concrete operational and formal operational. The sensorimotor stage focused on children who learned about the world through senses and motor behavior, and was during the ages of 0-2 years old. Afterwards, the preoperational phase, lasting from 2-7, the children begin to use language, display egocentrism, and have still not developed an understanding of conservation. The third stage at 7-11 years old is known as the concrete operational stage, where they begin to harness a knowledge of conservation, and use reasoning and logic to solve dilemmas. The last stage, formal development, involves people 11+ years old. This stage focused on abstract thinking. 

This was a great theory to explain the evolution of our behaviour and thoughts as we age, and which milestones we surpass every few years that contribute to our development. Armed with this knowledge, Kohldberg took these principles to create the Moral Development Theory. This involves moral reasoning, and is directly correlated to our cognitive development. 

The Moral Development Theory focused on childhood to adolescence development and our moral reasoning as we aged. According to Kohlberg, there were 3 levels of reasoning, each with two stages in progressing order. Level 1 is the preconventional stage, that consists of actions and behaviors being driven by obedience and eventually, self reward. This is seen as the least developed way of thinking. The second level, known as the conventional level had the notion that our behavior is driven by social approval and conforming to the social order. Lastly, level 3 is called the post conventional stage, and is the most developed way of reasoning. Here, peoples actions are influenced by social order, individual rights and universal ethics. 

Overall, we can compare both these theories since they are somewhat related to each other. They both focus on cognitive thinking and what influences our behaviour and actions. Both illustrated the fundamental skills and critical thinking we obtained, and how we may have developed them. They both showed important milsteones to know when we have reached a certain stage. Specifically, both related their findings to children as they aged into adolescence. 

Both the Moral Development Theory and Cognitive Theory have garnered a lot of attention over the years, and have been important in understanding how the human mind functions. They were both detrimental to the evolution of our knowledge and paved the way for research and learning in childhood development.

typeData.textContent: Flynn effect: the persistent rise in IQ with each subsequent generation

nodes.title: Reasons behind a consistent rise in our average IQ scores (Jingxin Guo)

typeData.textContent: why

Researchers have spent years speculating the causes of the Flynn effect. However, recent evidence from several countries suggests that IQ has stagnated and may be declining. This has been called the anti-Flynn effect. Multilevel modelling has shown that the anti-Flynn effect has strengthened in more recent years. (Woodley of Menie, Peaherrera-Aguirre, Fernandes, & Figueredo, 2018)
In some Scandinavian countries - specifically, Finland, Norway, and Denmark - average IQs have been dropping around 0.2 points per year. Woodley & Meissenburg (2013) suggest three possible reasons for this decline: 
1. Statistics: some objects referenced in tests are becoming obsolete, improper statistical sampling
2. Cultural - environmental: cultural and environmental circumstances are worsening (opposite of some explanations for the Flynn effect)
3. Biological: dysgenic biological factors - suggests that IQ may be an unfavourable trait when it comes to reproduction or intelligence is an irrelevant factor in reproduction.
	However, Woodley of Menie et al. (2018) have found no correlation between the anti-Flynn effect and the Index of Biological State (which measures selection operating on g), rather there seemed to be a higher correlation between the anti-Flynn effect and immigration. As seen in the past, immigrants are more likely to do worse on IQ tests which suggests a cultural bias to the tests that puts them at a disadvantage.
Robson (2019) has suggested this may be due to schools targeting different skills. For instance, math skills may be perceived as having worsened because of increased use of calculators in class. 
In summary, regardless of the reason for the anti-Flynn effect, it is important to note that this does not necessarily indicate that this generation is dumber than previous generations. Rather, it more likely represents a cultural shift in behaviour/norms which implies that IQ tests should be constantly updated to take our changing world into account.

References: 
1. Meta Quest Clips. (23 Apr 2020). James Flynn: Why the Flynn Effect has Stopped in Scandanavia. Retrieved from https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AuUjjLL_GX4
2. Robson, D. (2019 July 9) Has humanity reached peak intelligence? Retrieved from https://www.bbc.com/future/article/20190709-has-humanity-reached-peak-intelligence
3. Woodley of Menie, M.A., Peaherrera-Aguirre, M., Fernandes, H.B.F., & Figueredo, A.J. (2018). What causes the anti-Flynn effect? A data analysis and synthesis of predictors. Evolutionary Behavioural Sciences, 12(4), 276-295. http://dx.doi.org/10.1037/ebs0000106 
4. Woodley, M.A., & Meisenburg, G. (2013). In the Netherlands the anti-Flynn effect is a Jensen effect. ScienceDirect, 54(8), 871-876. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.paid.2012.12.022

nodes.title: From the journal: why Flynn effect happens? (Jingxin Guo)

typeData.textContent:
Flynn effect is the phenomenon developed by Richard Herrnstein and Charles Murray, which points out the fact that there is a substantial and long-sustained increase in both fluid and crystallized intelligence test scores measured in many parts of the world from roughly 1930 to the present day. (Baker et al., 2015) Many psychologists have proposed their hypothesis to explain why this happens. However, there is no saying that can be agreed commonly until now. 


Jakob Pietsching and Martin Voracek, psychology professors of the University of Vienna, had studied 100 years of IQ-test scores in 31 countries and published a paper called One century of global IQ gains: A formal meta-analysis of the Flynn effect (1909-2013) to illustrate their findings. They used solid evidence to refute some hypotheses as well as provided with their own opinions. So Id like to share some interesting insights here.

	Education factor

A very popular proposal is that attending school can increase our IQ. Back in the 1960s, psychologists found that the IQ score of African-American children in some Virginia counties decreased at a rate of about 6 IQ points per year due to the closure of the public school. (Neisser, 1997) Pietschnig and Voracek also believe that education plays a role in our IQ but not as much as people say. They criticized schooling is unlikely to account for the full extent of the IQ gains, and in particular the large gains for fluid IQ cannot be attributed to better education. (Pietschnig and Voracek, 2015) 

	Nutrition

Nutritional deficiencies may limit body and organ functionality, especially for the first 2 years of life. (The Lancet, 2008) Also, Better nutrition can increase the size of head and brain. (Jantz et al., 2000) However, Although genomic imprinting in principle would be suitable to explain IQ gains, this hypothesis remains difficult to test. Although influences of genomic imprinting cannot be completely ruled out, in the light of the observed fluctuations in the slope of IQ test score gains over time, this mechanism appears to be insufficient to plausibly explain the observed pattern in our data. (Pietschnig and Voracek, 2015)

After analyzing these possible factors, Pietschnig and Voracek suggest that the prime candidate causes of Flynn effect would be the combination of both life history speed (such as factors that Ive mentioned above) and a reduction of pathogen-related factors. It should be mentioned that they don't elaborate on every possible reason discussed in this paper, but it's still worth paying attention to those arguments that would help us to explain why the Flynn effect happens

References:
1.	Baker, David P.; Eslinger, Paul J.; Benavides, Martin; Peters, Ellen; Dieckmann, Nathan F.; Leon, Juan (March 2015). "The cognitive impact of the education revolution: A possible cause of the Flynn Effect on population IQ". Intelligence. 49: 14458. doi:10.1016/j.intell.2015.01.003. ISSN 0160-2896.
2.	Neisser U (1997). "Rising Scores on Intelligence Tests". American Scientist. 85 (5): 44047. Bibcode:1997AmSci..85..440N. Archived from the original on November 4, 2016.
3.	Pietschnig, Jakob & Voracek, Martin. (2015). One century of global IQ gains: A formal meta-analysis of the Flynn effect (1909-2013). Perspectives on Psychological Science. 10. 282-306. 10.1177/1745691615577701.
4.	"The Lancet Series on Maternal and Child Undernutrition". 2008.
5.	Jantz, R.; Meadows Jantz, L. (2000). "Secular change in craniofacial morphology". American Journal of Human Biology. 12 (3): 32738. doi:10.1002/(SICI)1520-6300(200005/06)12:3<327::AID-AJHB3>3.0.CO;2-1. PMID 11534023.

nodes.title: Bias in IQ testing - Larry P. v. Riles (Sonya Sula)

typeData.textContent:
Delving into week 9, we are introduced to the topic of pro-social behavior,  and one of the new terms the textbook comes across is the idea of homophily. This is the tendency for people to form social networks, including friendships, marriage, business relationships, and many other types of relationships, with others who are similar (McPherson et al., 2001).

An example for homophily and the application of it would be religious groups. Church gatherings would have the ability to bring people with the same morals and ideologies together. Similarly, school clubs and teams often are made as a result of like-minded people wanting to work together. 

Although the idea of connecting with people like oneself seems like a no-brainer good idea, there are some real world risks to only surround yourself with like-minded people. 

Learning
Being surrounded by people only like you, opportunities for learning may be diminished.  This may be not having the exposure to different interests and entertainment, (music genres, games, sports, etc) missing out on different businesses and work (work relationships), or even missing out on learning about different cultures and beliefs due to racial homophily. Homophily can impact views on our world, general knowledge, and opinions.

Simplifying and Aggression

With the idea of homophily preventing someone from being informed about certain topics and lifestyles, being surrounded by a homogenized group of people may lead to a us and them way of thinking. This idea can clearly be seen in US politics, where the existence of only two political parties provides impacts of homophily, red vs blue. In our case, homophily exists in the form of individuals surrounding themselves with people of the same political stance. Because of their politically homogenized social circles, people see the other political stances as the enemy, as each side ignores the other despite important issues needing to be discussed. 

Below is a small article that goes more into the specifics of how homophily is present on social media: 

https://medium.com/@alisabethtullo/dangers-of-homophily-in-social-media-1e7d13ebe138#:~:text=So%20while%20homophily%20may%20lead,even%20been%20linked%20to%20terrorism.

The History of IQ Testing - Li Nan Qiu

typeData.textContent: The first ever modern intelligence test in history was developed by Alfred Binet (1857-1911) and Theodore Simon (1873-1961) in the year of 1904. The French Ministry of Education asked these two researchers to develop a test that could distinguish mentally retarded children from the normally intelligent, however lazy children. The result became what's known as the Simon-Binet IQ test. The test consists of many components including logical reasoning, finding rhyming words, and naming objects. The score for the test combined with a child's age provides information on the intellectual development of said child, and the IQ score is calculated via the formula (mental age/chronological age)x100. The test was a huge success both in Europe and in America.

Paul Broca (1824-1880) and Sir Francis Galton (1822-1911) were among the very first scientists to contemplate the measurement of intelligence. They came up with the idea of determining intelligence by measuring the size of the human skull. The larger the skull, the smarter the person. 

At around the same time, Wilhelm Wundt (1932-1920) used introspection to measure intelligence. Introspection is the human ability to reflect on their own thoughts. 

Nowadays, these methods of measuring intelligence are considered outdated and are no longer used for intelligence testing. However they were a fundamental part of the history of intelligence testing.

nodes.title: The History of Intelligence Testing - Li Nan Qiu

typeData.textContent:
Interest in intelligence and intelligence testing dates back to thousands of years ago. Paul Broca (1824-1880) and Sir Francis Galton (1822-1911) were among the very first scientists to contemplate the measurement of intelligence. They came up with the idea of determining intelligence by measuring the size of the human skull. The larger the skull, the smarter the person. 

At around the same time, Wilhelm Wundt (1932-1920) used introspection to measure intelligence. Introspection is the human ability to reflect on their own thoughts. 

Nowadays, these methods of measuring intelligence are considered outdated and are no longer used for intelligence testing. However they were a fundamental part of the history of intelligence testing.

Psychologist Alfred Binet was asked by the French government to identify students who needed educational assistance in school, because the government had passed laws requiring all French children to attend school. Binet and Theodore Simon, his colleague, then began developing questions that focused on attention, memory, and problem solving skills. Binet determined the ones who had predictors of school success through those questions. He realized that some of the children were able to answer more advanced questions, and based on the observation suggested the concept of mental age--a measure of intelligence based on children of a certain age group's average abilities. 

The first intelligence test that was then developed is known as the Binet-Simon Scale, and created considerable interest upon being introduced to the United States. Stanford psychologist Lewis Terman took the original test and standardized it with a sample of American participants. The adapted test is called the Stanford-Binet Intelligence Scale--the standard intelligence test used to U.S. The test uses a single number, the intelligence quotient (IQ) to represent a person's score. Since then the test has gone through several revisions but still remains a popular tool for intelligence assessment. 

Another intelligence test was created by American psychologist David Wechsler based on the Stanford-Binet test. Like Binet, Wechsler believed that intelligence involves several different mental abilities. But he was dissatisfied with the Stanford-Binet test's limitations. He published a new intelligence test known as the Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale (WAIS) in the year 1955. He also created two different tests for children: the Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children (WISC) and the Wechsler Preschool and Primary Scale of Intelligence (WPPSI). The adult version is now known as WAIS-IV. 

WAIS-IV contains 10 subtests as well as five supplemental tests. The test produces scores in 4 major areas of intelligence: verbal comprehension, perceptual reasoning, working memory, and processing speed. The test also gives two broad scores as a summary for overall intelligence. The full IQ score combines performance on the four index scores. The General Ability Index being based on six subtest scores. Subtest scores have been proven useful for identifying learning disabilities.

nodes.title: The History of IQ Testing - Li Nan Qiu

typeData.textContent:
The first ever modern intelligence test in history was developed by Alfred Binet (1857-1911) and Theodore Simon (1873-1961) in the year of 1904. The French Ministry of Education asked these two researchers to develop a test that could distinguish mentally retarded children from the normally intelligent, however lazy children. The result became what's known as the Simon-Binet IQ test. The test consists of many components including logical reasoning, finding rhyming words, and naming objects. The score for the test combined with a child's age provides information on the intellectual development of said child, and the IQ score is calculated via the formula (mental age/chronological age)x100. The test was a huge success both in Europe and in America. 

There are pros and cons to IQ testing that have been proven throughout history. During the outset of World War I, US army officials had to screen an enormous number of recruits. Psychologist Robert Yerkes developed two tests: the Army Alpha and Beta tests. The Army Alpha test is a written test, whereas the Army Beta test is made up of pictures for those unable to read or those who didn't speak English. The tests were taken by over 2 million soldiers in an attempt to determine which men were suited to certain positions and leadership roles. The test continued to be used in a wide range of situations outside of military. This is when problems arose. The tests were used to screen immigrants entering the United States. Unfortunately the results were used to make inaccurate, sweeping generalizations about whole populations, leading to immigration restrictions.

nodes.title: Theory of moral development ( Bita Ghorbani)
Howard Gardner's Multiple Intelligences Theory (Claudia Le)

typeData.textContent:
Developed by Howard Gardner, the Multiple Intelligences Theory describes how each person has at least 8 different intelligences. While everyone has the same intelligences, each person may excel more in a certain intelligence than others. 

Journalists, poets, and teachers excel in linguistic intelligence. They effectively express themselves in spoken and written language while some also show the ability to easily learn multiple languages. 

Those with high logical-mathematical intelligence have the ability to think logically and reason. People such as scientists and mathematicians easily see numerical patterns, identify solutions to problems, and work with abstract ideas. 

Musical intelligence refers to those who are capable of understanding pitch, rhythm, and tone. Composers and performers have skills such as recognizing notes and musical patterns, producing music, and distinguishing different instruments. 

People who excel in bodily kinesthetic intelligence can easily manipulate their body to perform tasks and move their bodies in certain ways. While some may use to skill to find a career in sports, many also become dancers and athletic coaches.

Choreographers, architects, and aviators have high spatial intelligence. People excelling in this skill are able to transform visual images and understand how objects move in space while also comprehending the relationship of these objects. 

Those who have high interpersonal intelligence may find themselves being a counselor, social worker, or salesperson. They are empathetic, being able to understand others' emotions and needs which may help them in social situations. 

In order to have some personal growth, one must excel in intrapersonal intelligence. Exploring one's inner personal feelings and putting them towards a goal to manage their life displays intrapersonal intelligence. One with high intrapersonal intelligence may have an idea of what they want their future to look like, they are highly motivated and know how they can achieve this goal. 

Biologists, ecologists, and environmentalists all excel in naturalist intelligence. They have the ability to appreciate the natural world and interact with objects, animals, and plants in the environment. This intelligence involves being sensitive to the world and may find a natural interest in the environment and weather. 

While the 8 intelligences listed above are distinct, interpersonal and intrapersonal intelligence are often combined to be called emotional intelligence. Having high emotional intelligence involves being able to respond to one's own and others' feelings effectively while showing empathy and being able to respond in culturally appropriate ways.

nodes.title: Measuring Intelligence with Binet's Scale (Claudia Le)

typeData.textContent:
While the eugenics movement focused on selectively mating people of desirable traits and weeding out those unfavourable, it originally came from measuring intelligence through IQ testing. Sir Francis Galton was the first person to invent some type of test for intelligence and his concept eventually led to many others developing a test of their own.

One of the next people to develop an IQ test was Alfred Binet, who was approached by the French government to develop a test to identify children who needed extra support in school. He eventually invented a practical test with tasks for children to complete which would correspond to their mental age. 

The children were presented with an object, which progressed to more complex items. Their mental was to be subtracted from their chronological age to calculate their IQ. It was quickly criticized by Stern though, who argued that a child's mental age should be divided by their chronological age and then multiplied by 100%. 

Binet ensured that his test measured skills that could not be learned in school but rather something that should come as as a second nature to the child. He additionally worried that the score coming out of his scale would lead to self-fulfilling prophecies. 

It was specifically stressed that Binet's test did not signify a level of intelligence but instead was to be used to identify child who needed extra support in schooling. However, Henry Goddard quickly introduced this scale to the United States, using it to indicate intelligence.

nodes.title: Types of Learning Disabilities (Taylor Swift-LaPointe)
nodes.description: The types of learning disabilities, including dysgraphia, dyslexia, dyscalculia, and the related disorder ADHD.

typeData.textContent:
Learning disabilities are cognitive disorders that inhibit an individuals ability to learn, particularly involving reading and language (OpenStax 2018; NILD Canada 2019). A learning disability has no effect on intelligence  an individual with a learning disability may be misclassified as intellectually disabled on an IQ test, when in fact most people with learning disabilities have average to superior intelligence (OpenStax). Most learning disabilities are due to genetic mutations, often inherited from parents, but they can also be caused by head injuries during or after birth. Environmental factors during childhood do not cause learning disabilities, but they may enhance its effects if a child does not receive the necessary support in its learning (NILD Canada 2019).

There are several nationally recognized learning disabilities, and this post covers dysgraphia, dyslexia, dyscalculia, and the related disorder ADHD (which is not a learning disability). 

Dysgraphia
--> "dys" = difficulty with; "graphia" = writing (NILD Canada)
Dysgraphia is characterized by the inability to write legibly and properly. An individual with dysgraphia struggles with the motor skills of physically writing with a pen or pencil. It is also associated with difficulties with other spatial abilities (OpenStax 2018).

Dyslexia
--> "dys" = difficulty with; "lexia" = words
Dyslexia includes the inability to read words correctly, spell words, and manipulate sounds when reading words (NILD Canada 2019). It stems from difficulty in sound processing of letters in words. An individual with dyslexia may struggle with spelling, including mixing up the order of letters in words, word recognition, and reading (OpenStax 2018; Learning Disabilities Association 2013).

Dyscalculia
--> "dys" = difficulty with; "calculia" = calculations and mathematics
Dyscalculia is a disability that causes difficulties in understanding numbers, including representation of numbers and processing of numbers (Learning Disabilities Association 2013). This results in problems with mathematics calculations (NILD Canada 2019). Dyscalculia has also been associated with difficulties in quantitative reasoning (Learning Disabilities Association 2013).

Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)
ADHD is not a learning disability, although 30-50% of children in the United States who have ADHD also have a learning disability. ADHD is a disorder characterized by hyperactivity, short attention spans, and difficulty staying focused on the task at hand (Learning Disabilities Association 2013).


References
Learning Disabilities Association. (2013, Sept 2). ADHD. Learning Disabilities Association of America. https://ldaamerica.org/disabilities/adhd/

Learning Disabilities Association. (2013, Sept 2). Dyscalculia. Learning Disabilities Association of America. https://ldaamerica.org/disabilities/dyscalculia/

Learning Disabilities Association. (2013, Sept 2). Dyslexia. Learning Disabilities Association of America.
https://ldaamerica.org/disabilities/dyslexia/

NILD Canada. (2019). Learning Disabilities. National Institute for Learning Development. https://nildcanada.org/learning-disabilities/

OpenStax, Psychology. OpenStax CNX. Oct 31, 2018. http://cnx.org/contents/4abf04bf-93a0-45c3-9cbc-2cefd46e68cc@9.30

nodes.title: Bilingualism and Creativity: A Hidden Superpower? (Lang Kuoch)
nodes.description: We already know that speaking another language can allow you to immerse yourself in different cultures and gain new career and educational opportunities. But could being bilingual increase your level of creativity?

typeData.textContent:
Could being bilingual (speaking two languages fluently) increase your level of creativity? Is it possible that bilingualism is a superpower that we could be overlooking when measuring an individuals comparative level of creativity? According to many studies conducted over the past couple of decades, bilingualism might just account for some of these differences.

Bilingualism is generally defined as the use of multiple languages in everyday life on a regular basis (Grosjean & Li, 2013). However, there is quite a bit of variation in how an individual might acquire bilingual skills in their life. People may become bilingual early in lifechildren may learn two languages from birth, or acquire their second language later, such as when entering schoolor, they may learn a second language to fluency in their teens or adult years (Dijk et al., 2018).

Research has shown that language and multiple experience with cultures may contribute to a richer environment than those of monolinguals (Wang & Cheng, 2016). As bilingual children often experience the customs, values, knowledge, and wisdom of two or more cultures, it is generally thought that this leads to a greater ability for creative processes. From a more linguistic standpoint, the language environments of bilingual children differ from those of monolingual children as they are exposed to two different vocabularies and two different conceptual systems underlying these vocabularies (Dijk et al., 2018). This increased ability to access a variation of linguistic knowledge may also explain why there might be a positive relationship between bilingualism and creativity.

In more controlled environments, bilinguals have been demonstrated to outperform their monolingual peers in problem solving, perceptual focusing, and the Simon task, which is a test measuring an individuals interference/conflict resolution (Hommel et al., 2011). In several other studies conducted between 2007 and 2017, findings showed that highly proficient bilingual children showed a higher rate of inter-representational flexibility (i.e., links between components) in their drawings compared to their monolingual peers, outperformed their low-proficient bilinguals on the RAT (Remote Associates Test), outperformed monolingual peers on originality and ability to violate a standard set of category properties in the ATTA (Abbreviated Torrance Test for Adults) and IAC (Invented Alien Creatures) tests, as well as scoring better on thinking beyond standard categories and in creative problem solving in the ATTA (Kharkhurin 2011; Dijk et al., 2018).

However, these higher cognitive abilities dont come without a price. In many cases, it has been shown that bilinguals consistently perform more poorly than their monolingual peers in verbal fluency tasks (Rosselli et al., 2000) as well as in verbal creativity (Kharkhurin, 2010). They are also shown to have performed worse on their elaboration and originality tasks in the ATTA test and perform significantly lower on the AUT (Alternative Uses Test), a task which involves listing all the purposes an object may have, with higher points awarded to not only quantity of responses, but also the degree of unique, original, or uncommon answers (Hommel et al., 2011).

Thus, it seems that bilingualism isnt the magic creativity booster that we once thought it was. This does not mean that speaking another language to fluency has no positive influences on an individuals intelligence or creativity, as was seen by and supported with many of the studies conducted on proficient bilinguals, but rather that there is a more complicated, not well understood relationship between the two. 

Works Cited:

Bernard Hommel, L. S. (2011). Bilingualism and Creativity: Benefits in Convergent Thinking Come with Losses in Divergent Thinking. Frontiers in Psychology.

Francois Grosjean, P. L. (2013). The Psycholinguistics of Bilingualism. International Journal of Applied Linguistics.

H.-C. Wang, Y. S. Cheng (2016). Dissecting language creativity: English proficiency, creativity, and creativity motication as predictors in EFL learners' metaphoric creativity. Psychology of Aesthetics Creativity and the Arts, 205-213.

Kharkhurin, A. V. (2010). Sociocultural Differences in the Relationship Between Bilingualism and Creative Potential. Journal of Cross-Cultural Psychology, 776-783.

Kharkhurin, A. V. (2011). The Role of Bilingualism in Creative Performance on Divergent Thinking and Invented Alien Creatures Tests. The Journal of Creative Behavior.

M. Rosselli, A. A.-S. (2000). Verbal fluency and repetition skills in healthy older Spanish-English bilinguals. Applied Neuropsychology, 17-24.

Marloes Van Dijk, E. H. (2018). Bilingualism and Creativity: Towards a Situated Cognition Approach. Journal of Creative Behavior, 178-188.

nodes.title: Psychological Testing Key Concepts Review (Sharon Rosalind)
Divergent and Convergent Thinking: Harmony of the Two (Rick Son)
Applications of intelligence testing: Military [Lukas Franz]
nodes.description: a quick look at military uses of intelligence testing

typeData.textContent:
From our readings and lectures, we know that military bodies employed intelligence testing, in various forms. The United States initially used Robert Yerkes army alpha and army beta tests developed in World War 1 to determine the intelligence of their recruits.
The readings and lectures did not go into any more detail. From a little extra research, it turns out the scores of these tests used to see if recruits were mentally fit to be active in the forces and discover those who would be good candidates for military academies or officer-training schools (Brandwein, 2011). If done effectively this methodology provides a better way of selecting higher-ups than the previous method of officers promoting whomever they see fit regardless of actual merit.

In the United States, intelligence tests are still carried out for military recruits however according to a 2007 archive of a recruitment website they students are now required to take a test called the CAT-ASVAB.

Conformity (Kenji Wong)
nodes.description: Examining how politicians use the idea of conformity to manipulate people.

typeData.textContent:
(The following node might be politically sensitive and people might disagree with my views. But I still want to share my thoughts as I believe it is important for us to hear different voices. I HAVE NO MEANS TO OFFEND ANYONE!)

According to the textbook, conformity is the change in a persons behavior to go along with the group, even if he does not agree with the group. A classical example of conformity/ obedience will be the famous Zimbardo experiment, also known as the Stanford prison experiment. The conclusion of that experiment revealed that people will readily conform to the social roles they are expected to play, especially if the roles are as strongly stereotypical as those of the prison guards. In this node, I will examine how politicians use this theory to segregate and manipulate people into fighting with each other and I will use the example of Nazis, and the HK police.

During WWII, Hitler dehumanized Jews as rats and brutally slaughtered millions of Jews and while looking into this painful history, I pounded the reasons behind his followers blindly listening to Hitler and conforming to his orders. I personally do not believe that all or even most of his followers had such a strong hatred towards Jews, which they would be obedient towards unreasonable orders such as manslaughtering. However, when comparing this to the recent HK protest and police brutality, things seemed to make more sense to me. I think that it all comes down to the significance of dehumanization, conformity, and power. Politicians first dehumanized the group of individuals, which are threats to the politicians. By referring Jews as rats, and the HK protesters as cockroaches, harming or even killing them seemed to be justifiable, especially when they are compared to pests. The next step would be conformity and it is achieved by segregation people and giving them certain powers. For instance, if you are one of the police officers, even if you have opinions towards the harming of people, most likely you are not going to voice out since the consequences of voicing out might lead to you losing the jobs and/or being isolated by the rest of the group. And as humans, we are group animals, which means we desire and feel comfortable being in a group. When we are within a certain group, we have to conform to the ideologies of that group, even if some of them strongly oppose your own. 

(Again, all of the above statements are just my own thoughts. I understand that people might disagree with my reasonings, but please respect my own thoughts. Thank you.)

nodes.title: History of Psychological Testing - Quiz (Carina Bi)

typeData.textContent:
History
Prior to the 1970s, hundreds of studies reported low correlations (0.2-0.3) between IQ tests and job performance. Schmidt and Hunter suspected that the large quantity of results were attenuated by various statistical artifacts, including sampling error, unreliability of measuring instruments, and restriction of range (Richardson & Norgate, 2015, p.155). The two created methods to correct the artifacts and the correlation was corrected to approximately 0.5. Many studies and meta-analyses since then have made strong connections between IQ and job performance (e.g. Ree & Earles, 1992; Schmidt, 2002).

Explanation
The consensus on why IQ is predicative of job performance is that people who are more intelligent learn the job relevant knowledge more quickly and in depth, resulting in better job performance (e.g. Hunter, 1986; Ree et al., 1995). The correlation could also be due to self-fulfilling prophecies, where the employers expectation causes the success of the employee through additional resource allocation (Byington & Felps, 2010).  

Emotional Intelligence (EI)
Many studies have shown that EI is predicative of job performance with some studies indicating a correlation of approximately 0.24 to 0.30 (OBoyle et al., 2011). Research also suggest that people with high levels of emotional intelligence cope effectively with high demands and stress which leads to better job performance and less job burnout (Gong, Chen, & Wang, 2019; Moon & Hur, 2011). Ct and Miners (2006) on the other hand, found evidence that in terms of job performance, low cognitive intelligence can be compensated by emotional intelligence. 


References 
Byington, E., Felps, W. (2010). Why do IQ scores predict job performance? Research in Organizational Behavior, 30, 175-202. doi:10.1016/j.riob.2010.08.003

Ct, S., Miners, C. T. (2006). Emotional Intelligence, Cognitive Intelligence, and Job Performance. Administrative Science Quarterly, 51(1), 1-28. doi:10.2189/asqu.51.1.1

O'boyle, E. H., Humphrey, R. H., Pollack, J. M., Hawver, T. H., Story, P. A. (2011). The relation between emotional intelligence and job performance: A meta-analysis. Journal of Organizational Behavior, 32(5), 788-818. doi:10.1002/job.714

Synesthesia, Creativity, and Mental Illness [Rebecca Yang]
nodes.description:
The possibility of a third factor in the relationship between mental illness and creativity.

This node summarizes some research I have done on this notion, as well as some of my thoughts and inferences in relation to the course material.

typeData.textContent:
[DESCRIPTION: The possibility of a third factor in the relationship between mental illness and creativity.
This node summarizes some research I have done on this notion, as well as some of my thoughts and inferences in relation to the course material.]

Synesthesia is a primarily congenital neurological condition where sensory input in one modality elicits a sensory experience in another modality (Wendler and Schubert, 2019). For example, someone could experience seeing a particular colour in response to music, or taste flavours in response to reading certain words.

Synesthesia has been reported in many famous artists and musicians, including Pharrell Williams, Vincent van Gogh, and Franz Liszt (English, 2019). This suggests that synesthesia likely has a strong connection to creativity.

After investigating this phenomenon using an experiment that administered the Alternative Uses Test (ALT) and the Remote Association Test, or RAT (a measure of divergent thinking) to both a group of synesthetes and controls, a research team discovered that the synesthetes outperformed controls on the RAT, but not the ALT (Ward, Tompson-Lake, Ely, Kaminski, 2010). Upon further analysis of the results, it was concluded that synesthesia may enable one to be higher in certain, though not all, aspects of creativity. However, people with certain types of synesthesia were much more likely than the general population to be involved in the creative arts. In addition, it was stated that those who possessed the ability to synesthesia-like associations tended to also be high in creativity (Ward, Tompson-Lake, Ely, Kaminski, 2010).

However, other research has shown that synesthesia may not be solely beneficial, as many studies have suggested that it is also linked to the presence of various psychiatric illnesses, particularly anxiety (Carmichael et al, 2018), ASD (Carmichael, 2015), schizophrenia (Carmichael, 2015), and OCD (Wendler and Schubert, 2019). One researcher has proposed that because synesthesia affects serotonin transporters, they are at higher risk for psychiatric conditions that involve serotonin (Carmichael, 2015).

As the Openstax textbook states, certain psychiatric conditions likely do in fact result in higher levels of creativity. However, that does not omit the possibility of a second explanation, more specifically one that involves synesthesia. Perhaps, in some cases of individuals with mental illness, creativity may be enhanced by comorbid synesthesia, and some creative individuals with synesthesia may also have comorbid mental illness. 

I would also like to offer the idea that, maybe, in the case of schizophrenia, an increased likelihood of synesthesia may help to partly explain why it is present in relatives of the sufferer but not the sufferer themselves. I infer that the extremely impairing nature of schizophrenia may keep the sufferer from engaging in certain tasks, many of which may be creative. However, as synesthesia is largely genetic, relatives of the individual may be able to experience the creative advantages of synesthesia without the hindrance of schizophrenia.


References:

Carmichael, D. (2015, November 26). Synaesthesia and comorbidity. Retrieved July 21, 2020, from http://hdl.handle.net/1842/15796

English, T. (2019, October 28). 9 Famous Artists Who Have Synesthesia and How It Affected Them. Retrieved July 21, 2020, from https://interestingengineering.com/9-famous-artists-who-have-synesthesia-and-how-it-affected-them

Ward, J., Thompson-Lake, D., Ely, R., & Kaminski, F. (2008). Synaesthesia, creativity and art: What is the link? British Journal of Psychology, 99(1), 127-141. doi:10.1348/000712607x204164

Wendler, E., & Schubert, E. (2019). Synaesthesia, Creativity and Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder: Is There a Link? Creativity Research Journal, 31(3), 329-334. doi:10.1080/10400419.2019.1631637
