nodes.title: Conformity-based Preference Falsification and Psychological Studies (David Manuel)
nodes.description: Explores the ways in which preference falsification (rooted in pressure to conform) may lead to confounding effects in psychological studies.

linkMetadata.title: Conformity-based Preference Falsification and Psychological Studies  PSYC 102 2020 Summer: Tapestry
linkMetadata.description: Spielman, R. M., Dumper, K., Jenkins, W., Lacombe, A., Lovett, M., & Perlmutter, M. (2018). 7.5 Measures of Intelligence. In. Houston, TX: OpenStax, Rice University.

typeData.textContent:
Preference falsification is a term that the economist Timur Kuran (1997) proposed in his book __Private Truths Public Lies__.
Kuran uses the term to refer to instances in which individuals falsify their preferences due to conformity. In deference to group norms, and perhaps out of fear of being excluded, individuals might conform by falsifying their preferences. 
Preference falsification appears to be a behavior that is based on our tendency towards conformity.
What might the consequences of preference falsification be?
One area in which preference falsification could lead to negative outcomes is in psychological studies (or studies in the social sciences more broadly).
Our text (Spielman et al, 2018) states that conformity is impacted by whether or not our actions are taking place publicly or privately.
    Research shows that the size of the majority, the presence of another dissenter, and the public or relatively private nature of responses are key influences on conformity.
How might one consider designing a study so as to minimize the potential that individuals will falsify their preferences based on conformity?
One solution might be to design a study based on surveys that participants fill out in the privacy of their own homes, rather than having a participant answer questions in a group setting or with an administrator synchronously present.
However, as we learned in chapter 2 (about research methods), people do not necessarily answer surveys accurately (Spielman et al, 2018). Some people falsify their preferences on surveys (perhaps in part due to conformity) even when they are filling their surveys out privately. Its possible that an individual might feel pressured to answer even anonymous questions based on what they perceive to be the group norms.
Since all studies anonymize the data received from participants, hopefully the effects of potential preference falsification on surveys can be minimized. Ideally participants will act based on the fact that they are answering surveys confidentially, and will therefore feel free to represent their preferences accurately when answering surveys.
However, the problem of preference falsification due to conformity might be more difficult to control for when using other research method. If our research method involves people interacting in-person/synchronously, the potential for the confounding effects of conformity to come into play may be higher as the sense of anonymity is at least partially lost. The potentially confounding effects of preference falsification might be of an issue in some experimental designs, in designs that involve face to face interaction, and in designs where multiple participants are simultaneously present.
References
Kuran, T. (1997).__Private Truths, public lies: The social consequences of preference falsification__. Cambridge: Harvard University Press.
Spielman, R. M., Dumper, K., Jenkins, W., Lacombe, A., Lovett, M., & Perlmutter, M. (2018). 7.5 Measures of Intelligence. In __Psychology__. Houston, TX: OpenStax, Rice University.

nodes.title: Non-conformity & reactance theory (Nick Wong)
nodes.description: Non-conformity & reactance theory

typeData.textContent:
Non-conformity
Reactance theory
Although many obey and conform to the social norms around us, some might not. The non-conformists are the ones who knowingly act against the situational norm due to their personal opinion. Neither normative or informational influence affected their attitude towards a certain topic. This could be due to many psychological factors, such as having faith, being confident, or simply being stubborn. It is important to note that non-conformity is different from having another opinion. It is a refusal to abide by conventional expectations.

Reactance

What does it take for someone to not conform? When do people not obey on expectations? When parents instruct their teens to do chores, most teens would not like their instructions even though they were going to do them anyways. No one likes being predicted and told what to do, it feels like the freedom of choice is being threatened. As a result, the person might not conform and intentionally delays the chores even though it is what was planned. This act displays the reactance theory. Reactance is defined as unpleasant motivational arousal that emerges when people experience a threat to or loss of their free behaviors(1). The amount of reactance increases as greater freedom is perceived to be threatened. Generally, it is often accompanied by anger, annoyance, and aggressiveness. Measuring a persons reactance as a trait requires the revised Hongs Psychological Reactance Scale. Hong & Fredda compose the eleven questions with the following four factors in mind(2).
- Emotional response to an unrestricted choice
- Reaction to compliance
- Resisting influence from others
- Resistance to advice & recommendations


Resisting reactance

Reactance often works against the role of the persuader. If we are the persuader, what should we do to prevent it? A study in France was done in 2000 by Pascual and Gueguen to discover the effectiveness of the But you are free technique. They went around in a mall in France and begged for coins(3). They asked the strangers in two different ways.
- Sorry, Madam/Sir, would you have some coins to take the bus, please?
- Sorry, Madam/Sir, would you have some coins to take the bus, please? But you are free to accept or to refuse.
The total amount of money they have received with the latter wording doubled the former. The experiment attacked the fact that people are more likely to say no if their freedom is threatened, they purposely minimize that threat towards freedom with the phrase But you are free to accept or refuse.

(1)Steindl, Christina et al. Understanding Psychological Reactance: New Developments and Findings. Zeitschrift fur Psychologie vol. 223,4 (2015): 205-214. doi:10.1027/2151-2604/a000222

(2)Hong, Sung-Mook, and Salvatora Faedda. Refinement of the Hong Psychological Reactance Scale. Educational and Psychological Measurement, vol. 56, no. 1, Feb. 1996, pp. 173182, doi:10.1177/0013164496056001014.

(3)Christopher J. Carpenter (2013) A Meta-Analysis of the Effectiveness of the But You Are Free Compliance-Gaining Technique, Communication Studies, 64:1, 6-17, DOI: 10.1080/10510974.2012.727941

nodes.description: An interactive quiz layered on top of a video that explores the experiments that contributed to our understanding of conformity, in an accessible and modern way.

typeData.textContent:
Obedience is defined as a form of compliance that occurs when people follow direct commands, usually from some authority. People often comply because they are concerned about consequences if they do not.

Most of us have experienced obedience as children and students, in many different environments. The first thing that comes to mind is with parents at home. Its not uncommon for children to be expected to obey their parents. As children, we often obey our parents so as to try and avoid negative consequences such as being sent to our rooms or being grounded. When we reach adolescence, we tend to crave autonomy and drift away from the absolute parental compliance that was prevalent during childhood.

As we distance ourselves somewhat from the authority of our parents, we are faced with new authority figures in high school and new social norms, which we are further expected to obey. We encounter teachers, coaches, group leaders, and are exposed to norms decided by classmates, peers, and friend groups. We also become more cognizant of the world, society, and institutions that may demand our obedience. For example, many teens get their first job and are introduced to structures of organizational authority in the workplace. Bosses, managers, and supervisors become new figures to obey.

Throughout our lives and as we develop, the expectations for our obedience is continuously evolving with us. From our parents as children, to teachers as adolescents, to bosses as workers and to laws as part of a society. It may be impossible to achieve true autonomy, since there will always be some authority to which we must obey in order to avoid consequences in life.

By Julia Gorrie and Bi Yu Li

nodes.title: Howard Gardner Multiple Intelligences      Peri Sheppard
Criticism of Howard Gardners Multiple Intelligences   Peri Sheppard

typeData.textContent:
Howard Garnders theory of multiple intelligences is a very popular theory of intelligences with tens of thousands of citations of his papers and books on google scholar, but its not without its issues. A large problem with Gardners theory is that there is a lack of empirical evidence supporting it. In fact there is evidence that Gardners intelligences correlate with each other and with the g factor (Visser, 2006) pointing away from the idea of distinct individual intelligences. There is also the difficulty that Gardners theories cannot be falsified. Its not possible in many cases to discern whether something like musical ability is a result of aptitude or acquired purely through practice.(Visser, 2006)  Despite being heavily criticized the theory remains very popular in the field of education. (Haier, 2009) The idea that each individual is uniquely smart can be argued to have some societal value even though its not rigorously supported. (Gardner, 1993)


References
Gardner, H. (1993). Frames of mind. Basic Books.

Haier, R., Colom, R., Schroeder, D., Condon, C., Tang, C., Eaves, E., & Head, K. (2009). Gray matter and intelligence factors: Is there a neuro-g?. Intelligence, 37(2), 136-144. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.intell.2008.10.011

Visser, B., Ashton, M., & Vernon, P. (2006). g and the measurement of Multiple Intelligences: A response to Gardner. Intelligence, 34(5), 507-510. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.intell.2006.04.006

nodes.title: Examples of the 8 types of Intelligence (Jenny Wong)

Discussing Gardners Multiple Intelligences (Amy Ly & Brent McLean)
nodes.description: A discussion on Howard Gardners multiple intelligence theory and possible other intelligences. We will discuss the benefits and critiquing this theory of intelligence.

typeData.textContent:
Howard Gardner disagreed with unitary intelligence and developed the idea of multiple intelligences to represent different abilities among individuals. The main eight intelligence types he presented included: Visual-spatial, linguistic-verbal, interpersonal, intrapersonal, logical-mathematical, musical, bodily-kinesthetic and naturalistic.

Critique (Amy Ly):

From observation, these eight intelligences are theoretical and cannot be falsified. How is it possible to show an individuals intrapersonal intelligence? What could possibly be used as measurement and what would be identified as moderate level of intrapersonal intelligence or the norm? These are my personal critiques which Im sure are shared by others. From a simple google, researchers have also argued that the proposed intelligences are talents, personality traits, and abilities that do not represent intelligence.

In an article written by John White (2006), he explains how Gardner come up with this theory of multiple intelligences. White claims that Gardner came up with these eight types of intelligence not from scientific reasoning, but using his own personal judgement. Gardner created these intelligences by categorizing activities he considered culturally important, such as dance, mathematics and painting. Also, these categories Gardner came up with are arbitrary in nature as he has no scientific reasoning behind them besides preference. White goes on to explain how Gardner assessed his multiple intelligence in an individual and quotes Gardner as saying a candidates intelligence is reminiscent more of an artistic judgment than of a scientific assessment. This quote shows that there is no scientific background or merit to Gardners theory of multiple intelligences as there is no scientific reasoning/experiment or a reliable and valid method to test the eight intelligences in this theory.

Benefits of this theory: (Brent McLean)
One of the most obvious benefits to Gardners multiple intelligence theory is how it allows for the branching towards a more expanded definition of intelligence. Having eight different types of intelligence allows for the expansion of what we can define as intelligence. We no longer have to perceive intelligence solely based on the empirical merits of performance in academic or professional settings. Rather, intelligence can be described categorically using Gardners theory. As each type of intelligence covers a unique perspective and ability, the consideration of who is considered intelligent is expanded using this theory. This has the potential to have positive social impact as we can be cognitively assessed and labeled by our natural abilities rather than assessed by the rather dulling and standardized method of the classic education system. To paint a picture, on a different scale with the same principle: an monkey ranks well below an eagle in its ability to fly but thats not to say that the monkey is any less viable of an animal in its abilities. As quoted by one of the most influential people of all time:

Everybody is a genius. But if you judge a fish by its ability to climb a tree, it will live its whole life believing that it is stupid.  Albert Einstein

This quote has provoking abilities in discussing the revaluation of how we define intelligence. Although largely theoretical and unproven, Howard Gardners theory on multiple intelligences has the ability to reduce the unequal scale of intelligence and better represent individuals abilities in a more detailed manner on a wider range of intelligence that our society could greatly benefit from if researched and expanded upon further.

Discussing Unofficial Intelligence Types Proposed by Gardner (Amy Ly & Brent McLean):
As discussed previously, Gardner came up with the eight intelligences simply due to preference. Although not discussed thoroughly in class lectures, he also proposed a few more possible intelligences one could possess. Listed below are some intelligences that he suggested:

    Existential Intelligence  Individuals ability to use collective values and intuition to understand others and the world around them
    Humor Intelligence
    Memory Intelligence
    Teaching-Pedagogical Intelligence  Teaching other people successfully
    Spiritual Intelligence
    Existential Intelligence
    Moral Intelligence

The reason these did not get included into his theory is hypothesized that they did not meet his personal criteria for what intelligence was.

References

White, J., (2006). The trouble with multiple intelligences. [Forum]. Teaching Geography. https://www.geography.org.uk/download/ga_prgtipwhite2006.pdf

nodes.title: The Anti-Flynn Effect from Flynn Himself (Sarah Wissmann)

typeData.textContent:
In the late 1900s, the American psychologist Robert Sternberg, proposed that intelligence is comprised of three parts: practical, analytical and creative intelligence. Sternberg titled these three forms of intelligence as the Triarchic Theory of Intelligence. Sternbergs theory provides a broader conceptualization of intelligence in comparison to most conventional or traditional theories.

Practical intelligence involves the person to find practical solutions by applying experience-based or tactical knowledge to everyday problems (Sternberg, 1985). This knowledge is often never explicitly taught in academia or verbalized (Sternberg, 1985). Therefore, this type of intelligence is sometimes referred to as street smart. Sternberg measured this type of intelligence by providing subjects with work-related issues that are commonly encountered in a number of jobs (Sternberg, 1985). These participants are then required to assess and rate the quality of a number of solutions for each problem (Sternberg, 1985). However, an individual that scores high in practical intelligence may not translate to having a high IQ score in traditional intelligence tests. Additionally, these individuals may or may not excel in analytical or creative intelligence. 

Analytical intelligence on the other hand, involves an ability to analyze, evaluate, judge, compare, and contrast. As such, individuals that score high in this category would tend to excel academically in problem solving, computations, and literature. One method Sternberg used to test this type of intelligence was by measuring the individuals information-processing components (Sternberg, 1985). This consisted of an encoding component and a inference component (Sternberg, 1985). The encoding component is the individuals ability to understand the definition of a word, while the inference component refers to the subjects ability to relate other words to the previously presented word that they were required to define (Sternberg, 1985).  

Lastly, creative intelligence involves imagination or creating nuanced solutions for a problem or a situation. This type of intelligence can also be marked by creative art works or inventions. Therefore, Sternberg tested creative intelligence by having his participants create products that involved writing, advertising, art, and science (Sternberg, 1985).

References
Sternberg, R. J. (1985). Beyond IQ: A triarchic theory of human intelligence. CUP Archive.

What is Dyscalculia? IQ and Learning Disabilities (Jenny Wong)
nodes.description: In our readings we have learned about the various types of learning disabilities such as dyslexia and dysgraphia. Here I will be explaining about a learning disability known as dyscalculia and the relation between IQ levels.

typeData.textContent:
There is a common misconception that all patients with a learning disability would also have a low IQ measurement. This is incorrect. An example of this would be patients with dyscalculia. People diagnosed with dyscalculia are unable to process the meaning of numbers and as a result completing mathematical problems is a very challenging task (Butterworth, 5). This disability is independent of IQ. Studies have shown that IQ level is not a good predictor of ones mathematical abilities. It is possible for people with high IQ levels to be dyscalculic (Butterworth, 8). Patients with dyscalculia could have normal cognitive abilities such as the ability to reason and memorize information, but they cannot deal with anything related to numbers. The opposite also exists where patients can complete complex arithmetic calculations but may have trouble with their memory and language processing (Butterworth, 108). 

Dyscalculia lasts throughout ones life. It can occur due to brain damage or genetic reasons. There are two types of dyscalculia: developmental dyscalculia and acquired acalculia. Developmental dyscalculia is believed to be due to genetic or congenital disorders (Butterworth, 2). Acquired acalculia is due to brain injury (Butterworth, 108). There are also social factors that contribute to dyscalculia such as a childs socio-economic environment (Haberstroh et al. 2019). The prevalence rate is approximately three to seven percent in the general population (Haberstroh et al. 2019). This rate varies between different countries. Some common symptoms of this disability are difficulty reading clocks, unable to do subtraction, addition, etc. As a result, people with this disability often face impairments in school and at work. 

Two important brain structures that are vital for the processing of numbers are the right and left parietal lobes and the frontal lobe. Damage to the parietal lobes will cause a person to be unable to make numerical estimations, unable to do familiar arithmetic calculations and other basic calculations (Butterworth, 75). The frontal lobe is important for solving new mathematical problems that a person has not encountered before. (Butterworth, 75) The brains of dyscalculics often have problems in activation and abnormal structure in the parietal lobes (Butterworth, 91). 

There are interventions in place to prevent dyscalculia from getting worse. Some researchers suggest teaching children about numbers using sets (Butterworth, 146). For example, the number four is composed of 1,1,1, and 1 or 2 and 2. To demonstrate this, rather than using numbers, the teacher could use blocks to show what the number physically looks like. Starting off with concrete material allows for dyscalculics to visualize what numbers represent. Researchers emphasize that gradual progress is the most important and to teach the numerical concept in small steps (Butterworth, 153). After teaching the concrete representations, abstract concepts should be taught such as mathematical symbols and numbers. The inability to understand numbers often causes children to have low self-esteem. There is evidence that proves that anxiety hinders the working memory capacity which contributes to the inability to solve mathematical problems (Butterworth, 156). Therefore, a comfortable environment is especially important to help reduce anxiety. Intervention can only help reduce the severity of dyscalculia and unfortunately a cure does not exist. 

References 

Butterworth, B., 2019. Dyscalculia: from science to education. Routledge, London.

Haberstroh, S., Schulte-Krne, G., 2019. The diagnosis and treatment of dyscalculia. Deutsches  
            Aerzteblatt Online. doi:10.3238/arztebl.2019.0107

nodes.title: Nature v Nurture Overview Video (Vismai Khanderao)
The Heritability of Intelligence and affects of the Environment (Vismai Khanderao)

typeData.textContent:
The topic of Nature v Nurture in terms of intelligence has been debated. The idea that intelligence is part of an external locus of control due to genes can have demotivating effects on growth, though the idea of intelligence relating only to environmental factors conflicts with studies of the IQ of twins raised apart (Bouchard, Lykken, McGue, Segal, & Tellegen, 1990).
While studies have shown that intelligence can be inherited from parents (nature), environmental affects have shown changes on IQ (Bartels, Rietveld, Van Baal, & Boomsma, 2002). In the past, the idea of eugenics has played roles in enforcing beliefs in superiority through genes and have led to tragic consequences for many. A more correct modern idea of nature v nurture can be seen with the Range of Reaction theory in which an intelligence potential is set through genes and depended on environmental factors and their appraisals, the potential may or may not be met to varying degrees.
This theory was reaffirmed with evidence of studies by Csikszentmihalyi & Csikszentmihalyi, 1993. In which children from a strong genetic background were shown to be greatly affected by extent of stimulation from the environment.

Sometimes when someone is bullied, people might say, if you are not wrong, why do others only bully you?

When someone is sexually harassed, people might say, you're the one who dressed like this, and you deserve it.

When something is damaged by someone else, people might say, You're the one who didn't take care of it, so you cant blame others.

Such phenomena often happen in our lives. It is called Victim-Blaming. Why do people always blame the victim?

Sherry Hamby, a professor of psychology at the University of the South gave her own opinion. I think the biggest factor that promotes victim-blaming is something called the Just-World Hypothesis. Its this idea that people deserve what happens to them. Theres just a really strong need to believe that we all deserve our outcomes and consequences.

Melvin J. Lerner, a social psychologist, conducted an experiment in the 1960s in which participants were asked to observe how others were shocked without making a mistake. Lerner observed that when participants found they could do nothing but just watching others being shocked, they began to belittle the victim. For example, they declared that the person being shocked was a bad person, even though the participants did not know who the person was.

Lerner argued that this is because one's inability to cope with the suffering of others drains the sense of security and controllability that participants have built up through the Just-World Hypothesis away.

The hypothesis suggests that people who tend to blame the victim fall into a fallacy of logic. They assume that the world is perfectly just, so disasters wont happen to people for no reason, and that they are hurt because the victim made mistakes.

nodes.title: Unconscious Bias in the Workplace (Cindy Hsu) [psychos]

typeData.textContent:
Attribution theory has real-life impacts in the workplace. Unfortunately, it affects our behavior towards others unconsciously, and usually works against marginalized groups of people. It can show up in interviewing decisions, work distribution, performance reviews, and even in mundane conversation. Being aware of its effects when interacting with others can help in creating a safe and inclusive work environment. Some types of unconscious bias include:

1) halo/horn effect: When our impression of someone affects what we judge their competence or character to be (e.g. we might assume someone who looks conventionally attractive to be better at a job). Halo effect refers to positive attributions while horn effect refers to the negative attribution variant.

2) affinity bias: We often attribute positive personality traits to people we identify as similar to ourselves (or in our "in-group"). When applied to hiring and management this can lead to a preference for candidates of a specific race or background (e.g. school), irrespective of their actual skill.

3) gender bias: Women are often attributed to being family-oriented, which may lead to employers trying to pry into their personal lives. They may also be seen as less competent than their male counterparts, creating a "glass ceiling" for career advancement. This means it becomes difficult to be promoted to senior or executive positions.

Sources
https://www.forbes.com/sites/pragyaagarwaleurope/2018/10/19/how-can-bias-during-interviews-affect-recruitment-in-your-organisation/#66718ab1951a
https://www.ciphr.com/features/unconscious-bias-in-the-workplace/

linkMetadata.title: Inoculation Theory  PSYC 102 2020 Summer: Tapestry
linkMetadata.description: Since a presentation that prevents both sides of the argument is generally more persuasive than a one-sided argument, it is often more effective as a propaganda technique to use a two-sided refutational presentation. In fact, it tends to increase the audiences resistance to subsequent counterpropaganda; this would allow the inoculation effect to be politically useful. For example, policymakers attempts to shield Americans from the communist ideologies during the Cold war should not have been to introduce mandatory public school courses on patriotism and Americanism, but rather, to teach even-handed courses on Communism that challenge their belief in democracy. As evidenced by research, this would not make them more vulnerable to Communist propaganda but would more effectively build resistance to its ideologies.

nodes.description: What is attribution theory?

typeData.textContent:
What is it attribution theory ?
	it is to describe why people are behaving the way they are. 
	attribute people's behaviour to their environment or current situation or to their personal dispositions.
Attribute people's behaviour to their environment is called external factors.
Attribute people's behaviour to their personal dispositions is called internal factors.
Fundamental attribution error :When people fail to recognize when the behavior of another is due to situational variables, and thus to the persons state.
EXAMPLE...
When your boyfriend  returns home from work, and upon opening the front door his girlfriend happily greets him and ask about his day. Instead of happily answering  his girlfriend , he yells at her, Leave me alone! Why did he yell at his girlfriend? In this case of  fundamental attribution error will be saying that he is a mean, angry, or unfriendly.
The actor-observer bias is the phenomenon of attributing other peoples behavior to internal factors (fundamental attribution error) while attributing our own behaviour to situational forces.
 
Self-service bias is that people attribute their successes to internal factors and our failures to external factors.
Example: If people get a great job, people think that they were particularly well qualified for the position, but if they could not get that same great job, they would think that the day was a particularly bad one to have interview on.
There are two different types of ways to explain people's behaviour
Externalizers: People who believe that events or situations are because of the factors beyond their personal control. 
Internalizers: People who take responsibility for their own actions, or who feel they have the power to do something about the event or situation. 
Work cited
Opentax https://openstax.org/books/psychology/pages/12-1-what-is-social-psychology

typeData.textContent:
In 1972, the social psychologist by the name of Irving Janis coined the term Groupthink and defined it as a phenomenon that occurs when individuals in a group modify their opinions to align with their belief of the group consensus (Yaline, 2018). However, due to group pressures and the deterioration of mental efficacy and moral judgement, Groupthink often leads to faulty decisions. As such, the group as a whole would tend to make more extreme decisions that an individual on their own would not perform. 

One of the symptoms of this phenomenon is the illusion of invulnerability or invincibility, whereby the individuals are overly optimistic of the situation and thus, take extreme risk (Yaline, 2018). Another symptom of Groupthink is collective rationalization. This is when members discredit warnings that are contrary to the groups beliefs (Yaline, 2018). Additionally, group members believe that their course of action is morally right and just which is represented by the symptom of belief in inherit morality (Yaline, 2018). Stereotyped views of out-groups is another a symptom where individuals hold negative attitudes towards others with differing viewpoints (Yaline, 2018). In addition to their negative attitudes, group members apply direct pressure on dissenters (Yaline, 2018). This symptom is apparent when the group views individuals with opposing opinions of their commitment as disloyal (Yaline, 2018). This leads to self-censorship, whereby members withhold their dissenting views and opinions to avoid appearing as disloyal (Yaline, 2018). Furthermore, group members exemplify symptoms of illusions of unanimity and falsely perceive that everyone in the group has reached a consensus (Yaline, 2018). The last symptom is when mind guards are appointed, which means that members appoint themselves to roles that involve safeguarding the group from adverse information that would alter the groups cohesion and compliancy (Yaline, 2018). Janis concluded that if these conditions exist, there is a reasonable chance that Groupthink may occur due to the perceived cohesiveness among its members (Yaline, 2018). 

In order to avoid Groupthink, members must apply critical thinking and deductive reasoning skills to analyze the situation appropriately (Yaline, 2018). Although resisting conformity can be difficult, recognizing ones own moral values and asking the appropriate questions to confirm what the right course of action is will prevent the negative effects of Groupthink. Furthermore, it is important to recognize the symptoms of Groupthink, use factual-based knowledge, and limit personal confirmation biases to decrease the likelihood of this phenomenon occurring. 

Reference 
Valine, Y. A. (2018). Why cultures fail: The power and risk of Groupthink. Journal of Risk Management in Financial Institutions, 11(4), 301307.

Self-Fulfilling PropheSelf-Fulfilling Prophecies and the Pygmalion Effect (Vismai Khanderao)cies and the Pygmalion Effect (Vismai Khanderao)

typeData.textContent:
Self-fulfilling prophecies is the idea in which the expectation of a persons behaviour affects the actions towards them. This is prevalent in cases where a false expectation is reaffirmed until it becomes true due to actions of the individuals. Similar to the confirmation bias, this can be detrimental to a study in many cases. 

A study by Rosenthal and Jacobson (1992) showed that when teachers were told that some of their students in their class had significantly higher IQ and that they would perform better than their peers, by the end of the year, these students who actually were average, did turn out to perform better in the end.[1]

In cases, it is not only just one-sided reaffirmation. One study showed that in a workplace setting, a leaders expectations of an employees behaviour can influence the employees expectation of the leaders behaviour as well.[2] This feedback loop reaffirms both expectations until both become true.

1. Rosenthal, Robert; Jacobson, Lenore (1992). Pygmalion in the classroom: teacher expectation and pupils' intellectual development. ISBN 978-1904424062.
2. Bezuijen, Xander M.; Berg, Peter T.; Dam, Karen; Thierry, Henk (2009). Pygmalion and Employee Learning: The Role of Leader Behaviors. Journal of Management. 35 (5): 12481267. doi:10.1177/0149206308329966.

nodes.title: Self-Fulfilling Prophecies and the Pygmalion Effect (Vismai Khanderao)

typeData.textContent:
Self-fulfilling prophecies is the idea in which the expectation of a persons behaviour affects the actions towards them. This is prevalent in cases where a false expectation is reaffirmed until it becomes true due to actions of the individuals. Similar to the confirmation bias, this can be detrimental to a study in many cases. 

A study by Rosenthal and Jacobson (1992) showed that when teachers were told that some of their students in their class had significantly higher IQ and that they would perform better than their peers, by the end of the year, these students who actually were average, did turn out to perform better in the end.[1]

In cases, it is not only just one-sided reaffirmation. One study showed that in a workplace setting, a leaders expectations of an employees behaviour can influence the employees expectation of the leaders behaviour as well.[2] This feedback loop reaffirms both expectations until both become true.

1. Rosenthal, Robert; Jacobson, Lenore (1992). Pygmalion in the classroom: teacher expectation and pupils' intellectual development. ISBN 978-1904424062.
2. Bezuijen, Xander M.; Berg, Peter T.; Dam, Karen; Thierry, Henk (2009). Pygmalion and Employee Learning: The Role of Leader Behaviors. Journal of Management. 35 (5): 12481267. doi:10.1177/0149206308329966.

nodes.title: Quiz on Conformation and Groupthink (Josh Li)
THE EIGHT STAGES OF DEVELOPMENT: VIDEO NOTES OVERVIEW
nodes.description: This node highlights the eight stages of Psychosocial Theory of Development that are thoroughly explained in the linked video.

typeData.textContent:
1. Infancy: Resolve the task of Trust vs Mistrust (Identifying a responsive or unresponsive caregivers -> TWO OUTCOMES: safe predictable space or anxious and fearful)
2. Toddlers: Resolve the task of Autonomy vs Shame and Doubt (Establishing independence or dependance -> TWO OUTCOMES: independence or low self-esteem)
3. Preschool: Resolve the task of initiative vs guilt (Learning to plan and achieve goals while interacting with other -> TWO OUTCOMES: self confidence or guilty)
4. Elementary: Resolve the task of Industry vs inferiority (children beginning to compare themselves to others to see how they measure up -> TWO OUTCOMES: sense of pride or inferior feelings)
5. Adolescence: Resolve the task of Identity vs role confusion (Constant search for identity -> TWO OUTCOMES: strong sense of identity or weak sense of identity)
6. Early Adulthood: Resolve the task of Intimacy vs isolation (developing a positive self-concept in adolescence -> TWO OUTCOMES: strong intimate relations or lonely emotional isolation)
7. Middle Adulthood: Resolve the task of Generativity vs stagnation (finding your life's work and contributing to the development of others: volunteering, mentoring and raising children or not contributing to the development of others -> TWO OUTCOMES: good self development or stagnation/little self-improvement)
8. Late Adulthood: Resolve the task of Integrity vs despair (Evaluating past life experiences and coming to a conclusion -> TWO OUTCOMES: A sense of satisfaction or a sense of failure)
